content:
er 26, 2013
												Ohhh yeah look at that grass! These leaves are rendered beautifully. And, my god, look at the water, I can see my perfectly modeled reflection! Can you run Crysis, or can you not run Crysis? That is the question. If you can, you are one in a million. You are part of an elite organization dedicated to the eradication of visible polygon edges. You strive to inform the world of the dangers of trillinear filtering. But you also laugh as you run 5 different instances of Crysis at the same time, while the average gamer struggles to complete a game of minesweeper. As you watch your maximized particle effects without frame tearing you get a sense of superiority that is, well, frankly justified.Besides prestige and graphics, Crysis does offer great gameplay. The plot makes you feel, it makes you want more. The freeroam approach to objectives lets you choose your style. And at the end of the game you are just left in amazement at the 10 hour, non-stop ♥♥♥♥♥♥ you just had.So If you want to inflate your ego or just want a fantastic game pick up a copy of Crysis today... if you think you can handle it.

content:
y 12
												This isn't a bad game at all. It's one of the greatest shooters of all time and 10 years later it still holds up. From what I hear this game is also used more of a tool rather than a game as a benchmark for pc gaming rigs. It even gives some modern gpus a run for their money barely passing 60 fps. High end rigs back then could barely run this, let alone at MAX. Truly a testament of it's time. But that's not why I give this game a negative review. Don't let my playtime fool you, I have the original retail copy of this game and wanted a digital copy. It's the only reason I got the Steam version. The steam version of the game is just terrible. It uses 3rd party DRM (SecuROM) that is not equipped to run on modern operating systems like Windows 8 or Windows 10. It doesn't work because it doesn't include the x64 files to work on newer windows OS, unless you own the retail copy. My retail copy works fine on Windows 7 with no problems what so ever. The Steam version works on Windows 7 however if you spend a little bit of time in the menu section or when you pause it, the game freezes. There is no need for 3rd party DRM since Steam is already the DRM. My advice, get this game on GOG instead. DO NOT bother with the Steam or Origin version of the game. The game is a 10/10 but the Steam version is a 3/10.Buy it here instead:https://www.gog.com/game/crysis

number of helpful: 100 of 114 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
y 29, 2014
TL:DR? See ConclusionNOTE: I originally finished the game using my disc based copy of the game bought in 2007. I bought it again on steam because it was included in the Crysis Franchise Pack.INTRODUCTION:One of the rare PC Exclusive titles to break free from the Console's restrictive and dated hardware. Crysis 1 was the benchmark for most PC games back in 2007 until it was finally replaced by Metro 2033 in 2010.Crysis follows the story of Jake "Nomad" Dunn, member of a Delta Ops Nano Team tasked with infiltrating an Island currently occupied by North Korean Forces. Not soon after landing, the Delta team finds out that the KPA is the least of their worries.PROS:+ Cutting Edge Graphics: -Considering this game was released in 2007, Crysis can still go toe-to-toe with the 2012 game Far Cry 3. Back then, almost 95% of all PCs in the world could not run Crysis on its maximum settings. Crysis 1 was meant to be a PC only exclusive mostly because the developers really wanted to push both their creative freedom and raw hardware power. This is the game also spawned the internet meme: "But can it run Crysis?"+ Innovative Gameplay: -This game was the first to introduce the Nano Suit which added a wide variety of new approaches to missions and objectives. A Quick hand and good reflexes are needed to fully utilize the Nano Suit's power.+ Pseudo Open World: -Its not Sandbox, but it's not linear. Each mission objective involves a map of gigantic proportions where you can go and carefully plan out your strategy before going in a mission. Like what I said in my SW: Republic Commando Review, not every game needs to be sandbox. Crysis 1 had a good style by giving enough freedom while keeping the player in a directed flow in the story.CONS:- Terrible Optimization: -Although it was the Graphical Flagship of its time, the devs mainly focused on sheer brute force power of the GPU but made so little optimization. If properly optimized, most mid-range PCs could have ran this game a bit better.- Unresolved Bugs: -6 years and some of the bugs from the first release still persists. Downloading some of the latest patches actually causes a bug. Not game breaking but terribly annoying.- Resolution Problem: -You may or may not encounter this problem but the game seems to have a problem doing a full screen with a 1920x1080 resolution. To fix this, you'll need to edit the settings via note pad.CONCLUSION:MUST HAVE. One of the landmark games that dared a primarily Console dominated market to shine a great light once more to the PC.Additional Note: This is not a fast paced action game like COD or Battlefield. This game actually requires some planning and tactical movements to get the job done, specially in some of the harder difficulties.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

												After what....six years now?....this is still one of my faves. I still come back and play it periodically. Never get tired of the skulking around you can do, then open up fire on a few baddies for a while....then go back to skulking. This and the expansion pack Crysis Warhead are just a kick. Sort of like Call of Duty meets HL2, but with more hi-tech baddies and then some pretty mean aliens both big and small. Exceptionally weaponry at times as well. It's engaging on a lot of levels. You get your action on for a while. You get to sneak up on enemies and eliminate them in fun and interesting ways. And it challenges you to find sneaky means of taking them out. Even cooler: there are dozens of ways of attacking, and you can go back when replaying and try various new things and methods.Even better: it's as complex and slow-moving as you want, or you can force combat into a faster pace. Out-freaking-standing game

content:
er 25, 2013
												This game is well-known for being beautiful, but to desribe it only as eye candy really sells Crysis short.  There's a lot to enjoy about the gameplay, especially how it breaks up the old "series of chest-high-walls" shooter formula.As a super soldier your suit contains a variety of powers that can be toggled between:  super strength (enhancing melee abilities), super speed, maximum armor, and active camouflage (which makes you truly invisible to enemies who haven't seen you yet).  Active camo is the true selling point, learning to use it (and honestly, abuse it) is what keeps you alive.  Your character is not well suited for going in guns blazing, you'll rely on stealth and run-and-gun tactics against enemies who prefer to hunt you instead of bunkering down behind a chest high wall.  In general, human enemy AI is fantastic and pushes you to quickly learn how to survive a Crysis fire-fight.Weapons customization is another well-done aspect of Crysis.  The same gun can be customized to a short/medium range spray-and-pray style semi-automatic, or a long-range silenced sniper with a scope and laser sight, all pretty much on-the-fly.  So while the number of unique weapons is actually pretty small (5 or 6 maybe), you can get a lot more mileage out of them through customization.  While the first stretch of the game fighting human enemies is very fun, the game has an abrupt change when you begin to encounter mostly aliens.  I definitely found this part much less enjoyable, it seems more about showing what you can do with the Cry Engine than keeping the game fun for the player.  My level of interest dropped off pretty sharply, to the extent that I didn't even finish the game.That doesn't mean I'm not glad I bought it (I definitely still recommened it), and you may not have the same experience I had.

content:
y 19
												Would I recommend this game on it's own? Yes. Absolutely. Not only does it have amazing semi-open world gameplay, but it's graphics still hold up surprisingly well today. Which is amazing when you consider that this game came out 10 years ago! However, I cannot with any amount of seriousness recommend the Steam version. For some reason, EA completely neglected to include the latest update patches and the 64-bit version (which is the ONLY version PCs with AMD FX series CPUs like mine can run). I did manage to get the game to run without crashing on startup by manually installing the 1.21 patch and the executables for the 64-bit version myself and launching the game with a fan made .bat file but the point is, why do I HAVE to do all of that just to get the game to run? Doesn't the fact that I still had to manually patch the game myself kind of defeat the purpose of the Steam client? What's even worse is that from what I've heard, this problem isn't limited to the Steam version. The version sold on EA's own Origin service has the exact same problem!If you want to try this game for yourself, get it on GOG. Not only does the GOG version actually have both the 1.21 patch and the 64-bit version included from the get-go, but since it's a GOG release, it also has the nice added bonus of being DRM free as well.

content:
r 21, 2014
												Anyone who has heard of Crysis knows it is still heralded to this day as a benchmark for graphics. Based on the Cry Engine 2, even now it is absolutely stunning. But more importantly its actually a brilliant game all round. The story is pretty standard, you are a special force operative kitted out with a "Nano Suit" which allows you to perform as a super soldier, whilst on mission you discover an Alien species which are plotting to invade the world (or so it seems). Voice acting is pretty good, the facial mapping is OUTSTANDING! But the key point that won this game for me was the true freedom it provides you in how you play. The map is very open, leaving it up to the player how you approach each objective. You can switch your suit to max armour and plow straight through the next check point murdering people left right and centre... you could turn on your optic camoflage and sneak through without a soul knowing, you could buff your strength, pick up an explosive barrel, hurl it at the building and watch the Crytek physics bring the roof down upon your foes. It really gives you the freedom to play it in a way that suits you and that is why I would recommend Crysis.

Ultimately, I have a good feeling after finishing it and that is the most important factor for me.Anno 2013, Crysis still is a stunningly beautifull game, and you no longer need extra-terrestrial hardware to play this game on very high settings. However, the last level is very demanding on the system, and I had to run the game in DirectX 9 mode to be able to stay above 60FPS (just add -dx9 as a startup argument).So, all in all, do I recommend this game... yes (if you can pick it up a at a discounted price of course).

content:
er 21, 2014
												It took me a while to be fond of this game as I played it years ago and while my rig met the minimum requirements (almost reached the recommended ones) it had a hard time running Crysis on it properly. There were numerous glitches, audio issues and frequent CTDs.But you know what? Putting the technical difficulties aside this is a damn fine game! You play Nomad, a special forces soldier who wears a so-called nanosuit. The story takes place in the future and the objective is to find out what happened on the island previously seized by Koreans. While you traverse through the deep jungle and small settlements you notice two things: the game is stunningly beautiful (there was a reason for the high system reqs) and that by hiding-shooting you cannot eliminate your foes. You need to utilise your nanosuit. You can bring up a special menu and select from various abilities. Speed makes you faster, Strength allows you to melee your foes or throw bigger objects and Stealth makes you invisible. All drain your energy bar (which will refill automatically, but slowly) and I do not have to mention that Stealth is the most exciting and most useful among all. Oh, yes, there's a 4th power enabling you to take more damage.Enemy AI is great - they respond to the noises, work in squads and will try to find you even if you are invisible. On greater difficulty settings they speak Korean so you do not understand what commands they give to one another.Occasionally, the game throws in some scripted cutscenes - these look good and also interesting. By looking at the pictures on the store page one can guess what they'll find (and what the army was really looking into), but let's not spoil it here.Crysis is a stunningly beautiful game (even today considering it's more than 5 years old) and makes for an interesting, action-packed ride.WARNING: This review is based on playing the game on a 32-bit operating system. As per the feedbacks on the store page and amongst the discussions people detail further issues when it comes to 64-bit systems. I understand there is a workaround which has been tried and found good, still, this is just to let you know that before the purchase you should look into this.

content:
29, 2014
"ADAPT. ENGAGE. SURVIVE.I've never ever felt so confused about rating something I have just finished. At the moment I'm talking about story and its side of game because other parts of game (which we'll be talking next) are perfect.On the release date (2007) was this game truly revolutionary. In that time game's graphic was something unbelieveable. And still when we're comparing nowadays games or games from at least from 2010+ we can see, that Crysis is still next step above them and not in graphic, but in whole gameplay, even stealth and sometimes AI. This game is damn 7 YEARS OLD for God's sake and still nowadays developers are not even able to put their games to level Crysis was in 2007 which's really unbelieveable. My PERSONAL opinion is, that if there weren't aliens and SCI-FI side, it'd be one of the best FPS games ever been made. At the moment I got my hands on my head, and thinking of words which could describe the first hours of game. Alright, I'll divide this game to 2 parts ... 1st with Koreans and 2nd with Aliens. If the whole game was only about Koreans .... I still have no idea why they've put Aliens in it... Just because they had to think of new story? Ridicolous, since the story flew 5 hours without problem and without mentioning Aliens... They really have could let it in only.There was mentioned stealth, so let's take a look on it. It's really different, than in nowadays games. Now, when you hide into creek or tree, or just some textures which obviously should cover you, you're automatically spotted because in source code they're just textures, but in Crysis somehow you was able to cover in creek or tree and enemy could be few feets away from you, and he didn't spot you which's realistic I'd say. But of course only if you stood still. If you made a move, he could hear you obviously, so also as I said AI is pretty good made here. When you're in firefight, they won't rush you, they'll wait for you, throwing grenades on you, but in open field, they wan't to crush you from sides which really doesn't matter since you got Nanosuit... Multiplayer is totally dead. No wonder when this game is 7 years old. Still you can find servers with 30+ players, but only sometimes, and they're different version than Steam version (Servers for cracked copies) and there are only 10 servers for Steam version which're empty and when there is someone, he's cheater anyway. MP won't change rating.To the end let's say, apart from fact there're Aliens it's still awesome, great, brilliant, and one of the best FPS ever been made, but not BEST. Crytek always knew how to make games (not these days .. NOTE: F2P). The ending was one of the worst I have ever encounter. Ending of game took me 10 hours in total and parts with Aliens was like 3+ hours.Bonus Point: FPS RevolutionRating: 9/10

content:
er 25, 2013
												Crysis is a  first-person shooter game developed by Crytek and published by Electronic Arts in 2007.An elite group travels to North Korea to investigate an artifact. While the player faces Korean soldiers and research facilities , an alien ship prepares to emerge and begin the invasion of Earth . Nomad  faces Korean forces and tries to defeat the alien threat . The game submerges us under incredibly detailed rainforests. The physics of the game is excellent . Apart from the story, one enjoys walking around the environment , breaking the palms, catching animals, piloting boats , swimming with fish , and driving around the islands.The graphics engine is the successor to Far Cry . It was a real revolution in real-time graphics . The image quality and texture is still among the best of all time . This makes the game very immersive . It took five years after release to play the game with very high quality settings and get  a reasonable experience. Many people spoke at the time of bad optimization when in fact the game has three times more polygons than his contemporaries , volumetric clouds , day- night phases and huge maps. Nothing compared to the fixed pixelated sky on a Call of Duty game .The player has a special suit that gives different powers or abilities for a period of time, such as invisibility , speed or armor. While it is not a Sandbox, it has  open maps that simulate the world much better than its very linear successor, Crysis 2. In that regard, it is even better than Crysis 3.The game was one of the best action games of 2007 but did not have many sales due to high specifications, hardware requirements and DirectX 10. It has two Secuels . Crysis 2 and Crysis 3 .While Crysis 3 surpasses some of its graphic , 1 remains the best game of the 3 .The game was released for Windows PC , PS3 and XBOX 360 before being ported to MAC OSX.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ESPAÑOL--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Crysis es un videojuego de disparos en primera persona desarrollado por Crytek y distribuido por Electronic Arts en 2007.Un grupo de elite viaja a Corea del Norte a investigar un artefacto. Mientras que el jugador se enfrenta a soldados coreanos e investiga instalaciones, una nave alienígena se prepara para emerger y comenzar la invasión de la tierra. Jake Nomad deberá enfrentarse a las fuerzas coreanas y alienígneas para intentar derrotarlas. El juego nos lleva por selvas tropicales increiblemente detalladas. La física del juego es excelente. Al margen de la historia uno disfruta de pasear por el entorno, romper las palmeras, agarrar animales, pilotar lanchas, nadar con peces y manejar vehículos por las islas. El motor gráfico es el sucesor del Far Cry. Fue una verdadera revolución en cuanto a gráficos en tiempo real. La calidad de imagen y texturas sigue estando entre las mejores de todos los tiempos. Esto hace al juego muy inmersivo. Recién después de cinco años pudo jugarse el juego con la calidad máxima activada y una experiencia razonable. Mucha gente habló en su momento de mala optimización cuando en realidad el juego tenia tres veces mas polígonos que sus contemporaneos, nubes volumétricas, fases dia - noche y mapas enormes. Nada que ver con el cielo pixelado y fijo de un Call of Duty. El jugador posee un traje especial que le confiere poderes especiales por un lapso de tiempo, como la invisibilidad, la velocidad o armadura. Si bien no es un Sandbox posee mapas que simulan un mundo abierto mucho mejor que su muy lineal sucesor, el Crysis 2.El juego fue uno de los mejores juegos de acción de 2007 aunque no tuvo muchas ventas debido a las altas especificaciones y el requerimiento de DirectX 10 para aprovecharlo al máximo. Posee dos seculas. El Crysis 2 y el Crysis 3. Si bien el Crysis 3 lo supera en algunos de sus aspectos gráficos, el 1 sigue siendo el mejor de los 3. El juego se lanzó para PC bajo Windows, PS3 y XBOX 360 para luego ser portado a MAC OSX.

												I guess I got to this one late. Actually the only reason I bought this was because I got a new PC that actually can play games and, with Crysis having once been "that game for crazy good gaming PC's," I decided to check it out for that reason alone.Even after ~8 years, it's quite a pretty game on max settings. It's also a decent shooter with a giant open world that allows for varied approaches towards completing objectives. But it weakens in the later parts of the game as it becomes more linear and all about fighting off hordes of enemies coming to attack you. Also the ending is kinda abrupt, but I guess they did that so they could cash in on some sequels (and they seem to have done exactly that).So... is it worth getting? I guess. It's not a bad game at all, though I can't see myself playing through it again. Play it for curiosity's sake, then put it away. :o♥♥♥♥ EA.

												The graphics in this game are amazing, even when compared to a lot of current-gen games. This was truly ahead of it's time. Of course, there are some minor flaws which are commonly seen in first-person open world games, mainly problems with the enemies being dumb as soup cans even on difficulties above easy. But, in defense, the game was made to be eyecandy and not to be a gameplay masterpiece. Still, the stealth, the weapons, the vehicles, the open world and the missions all make Crysis most certainly worth it's price tag. Also, you're best off getting the maximum edition, because it includes Crysis Warhead, which just adds to the experience. So, despite it's flaws, I give Crysis a solid 9.5/10.

number of helpful: 20 of 21 people (95%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2016
												The game may be 9 years old, but the graphics can still compete with many new releases today.Sure there may be some assets that are not wuiet up to todays standards of games that are considered looking great today. For instance the palm trees may be a bit edgier than more modern trees that use tesselation. or some rock textures that aren't quiet as crisp as they could be. Everything else when it comes to graphics still holds up very well to new releases.When it comes to performance the game should runs just fine on maximum graphics, as long as your system has decent hardware. im thinking soething like a gtx660 and some i5 should handle it just fineNow that we got the "graphics part" out of the way.Let's get to the actual review:I played this game 9 years ago when it came out and I loved it. The Physics are some of the best I've seen in any game to date. You can destroy entire huts. Without having them collapse in a predetermined way. but instead theyll actually react physicly correct to how you interacted with them.There are 10 Levels in the game. That are all pretty big. So there is no pre-determined way to go like in call of duty. Each of the levels are several square kilometers big that you can actually walk on. And there aren't really any areas that feel empty.The AI is pretty smart for the most part. On the highest difficulty they are pretty hard to beat at times. However they aren't perfect ofcourse either. For instance in the 1st level there is a guy in a toilet. and 8/10 times when he gets alert to you he runs into the wall of the toilet instead of out through the door.The Story is probably the games weakest feature, which doesn't say it's bad. It's just nothing particularly special either. That beeing said, as a little side note: The story in Crysis 2 is actually quiet an improvement over the one in Crysis 1.And now the most important gameplay element: The nanosuit. For me this made it for one super cool, cause you are some super hero kind badass (with a slightly more grounded background lore to how the powers work than most comic book super heroes). And also I think it makes for some very fun options gameplay wise. You have great mobility with speed and strength mode. you can choose to fight as a tank with armor mode (although you still die very quick on delta difficulty so its not crazy overpowered) and you can play very stealthy with the cloak mode (which makes you almost but not completly invisible).All those abilities use the suit's energy, so they can not be used indefinitly.And the best thing is you can switch in between the diffrent suitmodes at any time, so you can adapt your playstyle to the situation at any given time.Last: The Multiplayer:So appereantly the multiplayer doesn't work anymore due to the service it used (gamespy) shutting down. However there may be workarounds to still play online. And the LAN mode still works ofcourse.I personally didn't bother much with the multiplayer in crysis 1. Back when I tried it it seemed alright, but I don't think it lived auiet up to the potential of multiplayer fun there could have been with the nanosuit. crysis 2 was an improvement in that regard in my opinion.So all in all Crysis 1(and I'm mainly referring to the singleplayer here) in my opinion is one of the best shooters ever made. And I'd recommend it to anyone who hasn't played it yet. (9/10) (10/10 if you choose to ignore the slightly weaker story)

number of helpful: 29 of 37 people (78%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
er 16, 2014
												Warning, contains mild (Edit: heavy) spoilers.Never having played the famous Crysis, I thought I'd finally give it a shot and find out what the fuss is all about. Naturally, since I played this in 2014, my perspective on the game will be very different from the one who played it when it came out. But only an hour into the game, I realized why people call it such a revolutionary shooter for its time. I didn't play with any mods, yet I would've never guessed the game I was playing came out in 2007 judging from what it presented to me. This is due to the following reasons:- The vastness of the world and the graphical fidelity are overwhelmingly impressive for an FPS title this old. You can clearly see that the CryEngine is designed to push the limits on what's possible in terms of looks and scope. I was impressed by how open-world-y the terrain is, yet the missions are unmistakably straightforward... which turns out to be an incredibly fun combination in my opinion. Being dropped on a tropical island where you shoot people in a vast and open area offering multiple ways of approaching your goals is to my mind a great way to design an FPS. The level of detail is stunning to say the least for a 2007 title, I have seen much worse in considerably newer titles.- The gunplay, gun variety and AI are simply great. Shooting enemies feels fun, feels rewarding and feels challenging since the AI actively tries to hunt you down when you for example sneaked away again using cloak. One of the core mechanics, the exosuit and its accompanying suit powers offer great variety for both people who like to be stealthy or those who love to cause mayhem. I found a mix of these to be the most effective and entertaining. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it I think I never experienced as much satisfaction as when I blew up a truck with a rocket launcher while crouching in a bush with cloak engaged. The effects are mindblowing, as are the sound assets, just really immersive overall.- Performance is solid. With CFX 7950/7970 I easily manage 60fps, except for very intense scenes involving lots of explosions and stuff. FoV seems to be exceptionally high, I didn't see a slider for it in the menu, but it's at least 100 by default, which is great. Sadly there's a few bugs involving for example scripted events and cutscenes not triggering correctly when loading from quicksaves amidst a level, nothing game-breaking though. Also, 1920x1080 or higher resolution is not enabled by default, you have to manually adjust it in the config file, which is no big deal though.- The level design is interesting enough. While most levels feature open tropical island terrain with hilly, foresty areas, there's also a sequence where you are in weightless space, floating around inside a gigantic alien structure; very impressive and intriguing overall. The enemy variety is great too: From your usual infantry of all kind to jeeps, tanks, helicopters, boats to rather pesky flying alien crystalline squids with fast-firing energy weapons to a huge ♥♥♥ alien motherfugger in the process of sinking a motherfuggin aircraft carrier. It should be noted that you can drive jeeps, tanks, boats and helicopters yourself which is super fun if you like to shoot up stuff in the most classy way imaginable.Negative points? I have one major one, but perhaps it's not really valid since the game clearly doesn't focus on that aspect at all and never pretends to:The story is mindblowingly clichée and superficial: >Technologically augmented super soldier infiltrates fictional island under the control of evil North Koreans, gathers intel, blows up stuff, uncovers archeological project gone overboard, sleeping alien entity that feeds itself off energy awakens, causes major destruction, gruffy American general wants to drop nuke on island to kill off the monstrosity, super-intelligent scientists who always know it better advise against it, alien gets nuked anyway, becomes massively stronger, protagonist has to beat XXL format version of alien monstrosity using lots of missiles and a super secret prototype weapon which had never been field-tested but works like a charm (why wouldn't it?), escapes a sinking aircraft carrier and goes right back into the fight because he's a badass and a superhuman, dutiful soldier-tough-guy who has no fear and throughout the entire game requires no sleep at all. There, that's the plot in a nutshell for you. Not really intentended in the beginning but hey, these are spontaneous and minimally structured reviews after all so w/e. So there you go, awesome FPS, don't play it for the story, play it for the mechanics and the looks. This is how every modern military shooter should be. You can make a very linear, bland narrative without sacrificing diversity and creativity in terms of gameplay and mechanics. Crysis taught us this. No score here, read the damn review if you care for my opinion on it.

content:
er 31, 2013
												Do you miss first person action games like GoldenEye, Thief 2, and the original Ghost Recon? If you miss games that simply put you in an environment, gave you some objectives, and let you figure out how to do them without driving you down a rollercoaster, the original Crysis is arguably the last and most technically advanced game of this type to be developed. The visual achievements of the CryEngine have overshadowed the fact that this game, well most of it at least, is a shining example of objective-based game design released just before everyone took shooters in the complete opposite direction.The first level, which is shown off in the demo that’s available at crysisdemo.com as of this writing, is a perfect example of this. In a small bay occupied by a few enemy fortifications along the shore and some motorboat patrols, Crysis gives you two main objectives and an optional objective to tackle in any order. You can work your way along the coastline through the forts, take over a boat to zip around the bay, or whatever, through any combination of stealth and assault tactics.This continues through the next several levels which are sort of a linear chain of small sandboxes: a village you can infiltrate from multiple angles, a group of bases along a river, a harbor, and so-on. The level design in all these areas is quite good, always giving you options and setups for fire fights that never happen the same way twice. This is even true in the game’s more linear sections early on. In the early parts (more on that later), even when Crysis is a corridor it’s still a very wide corridor.I think the best way to describe the core game mechanics would be to call Crysis a simulation based on the original 1987 Predator movie. Your tools are Schwarzenegger-esque explosions and futuristic super powers. The nanosuit let’s you choose between super armor (the default), increased running speed, and a temporary stealth cloak. You’ll probably use the cloak the most but the other powers offer potential for fun combinations and interesting choices. Super strength let’s you jump higher, and you can combine it with speed for running super jumps. When sniping you can choose between staying hidden with the cloak or using strength for a more stable shooting arm.Behind the nanosuit the Crysis boasts a varied sandbox of shooter mechanics. Not only is there the ever-present option of stealth, but you can also lift and throw most objects at enemies and control various vehicles. Most buildings in the game are also dynamically destructible through the physics engine, which feels like it has a tangible effect on gameplay. Crysis even let’s you fit most weapons with a modest variety of attachments with a quick tap of the C key like different sights or a silencer.The reason you might hear a lot of people praise Crysis by saying “the first half” or “the first two thirds” of the game, is because for some reason it turns into a different, much worse game at a specific point later on. The later sections of Crysis are far more linear and introduce gameplay mechanics that while unique, just don’t work that well.  It’s probably best if you stop playing when you start a boss fight with a North Korean general. The most succinct thing I can say is at that point it feels like the level designers ran out of gas.The good parts of Crysis though will still net you at least around 10 hours of gameplay, and that’s just for one run. I consider Crysis to be a pretty replayable game just because you can approach its missions with multiple strategies, but also because each difficulty mode above normal changes things considerably.On normal you can pretty much toy with enemies using the nanosuit. On hard you can still play with them a little bit, but you have to be smart about it. Higher difficulties change a few core mechanics, and the deadlier enemies ensure you have to rethink the way you use the cloak and cover. Hard and Delta mode almost turn Crysis into a straight-up stealth game.Of course what Crysis is most well-known for is the “but can it run Crysis?” joke pertaining to the game’s harsh treatment of processors. Even after six years, Crysis is not an extremely easy game to run. My GTX 760 still only get’s 60 frames per second MOST of the time in 1080p. The consumer experience when you first install the game doesn’t make things easier either.Being from the early days of DirectX 10, Crysis forces it on you by artificially locking the highest graphics features behind DX10 when they are in fact available on DX9 just by editing the ini file or downloading a custom one. DX10 does little more than drag down performance of the already demanding Crysis.If you’re wondering if Crysis still holds up visually after six years, I think with vanilla settings it’s beginning to show its age, but still looks significantly better than most console games released in even the last couple years. Really, only the highest-end recent PC games (Crysis 3, Metro, Battlefield 4), and next-gen-console-only launch games like Killzone Shadow Fall beat it. It can still look impressive with custom ini files and texture packs though.I think it’s kind of a crime Crysis got labled as just “that really pretty PC game nobody can run.” In my opinion it’s one of the most underrated first person shooters of this past console generation (it did come out on consoles eventually after all), if not one of the best. It’s one of the last, if not the last of a breed of shooter that game designers seemingly forgot in the chase after Call of Duty’s popularity.

content:
, 2016
												While many reviewers are saying not to purchase it because it does not work in 64-bit systems, there is a way that allows it to work (though it is completely ridiculous that these steps are necessary). This is tested and working in Windows 10 Pro.What I did was to follow two different suggestions found here:Steam Community postand here:Youtube VideoStep 1:Download the Bin64 files from the first link then extract and copy the entire folder into the Crysis program directory.Rename the Bin32 folder found in the same directory to Bin32.BAK. Then rename the Bin64 folder you just copied to Bin32.Step 2:From the second link, download the Crysis.exe file found in the video description. In the newly renamed Bin32 folder (the one that was Bin64), rename the Crysis.exe file to Crysis.BAK. Next, copy the Crysis.exe file you downloaded from the Youtube link into the same Bin32 folder.Step 3:While still in the Bin32 folder, right-click on the Crysis.exe file you just copied and select Properties. In the Compatibility tab, check the box next to "Run this program in compatibility mode for:" and then select "Windows Vista (Service Pack 2)" from the drop down menu. Click Apply then OK. You're finished!Now the game can be launched from within Steam.

content:
8, 2016
Teal DeerDevelopers: CrytekPublishers: Electronic ArtsInitial release: Nov 2007Genre: FPS#Worth/NotWorth: #SoWorthExposition, Concurrence and SummationWhoever said this was a glorified tech demo had their head buried in a hole.Crysis is a truly open world first person shooter. Nothing before nor after (at least at the time of writing this) has matched its prowess of being able to almost literally do anything you can think of to complete a task or objective. You're given an experimental special ops nanosuit. A suit that has the ability to infuse strength, provide protection, increase speed as well as provide a stealth cloak. Limited only by the suits energy levels, these functions can be swapped on the fly. Aside from the suit you have a extremely modifiable weapon not to mention weapon pick ups that are additionally modifiable; from silencers, stocks, sights and auto/semi fire type can be exchanged at a whims notice. As well as vehicles and gun mounts to use, any play-style is immediately within your grasp. There is nothing quite like punching through a wall and blasting the occupants close range with a shotgun with full armor going “H.A.M.” and tanking it. With the dichotomy of attaching a scope, applying strength to steady scope sway and using a silencer to drop enemies from afar and then go in closer using your cloak and take them out with a pistol or however else you may desire. With all of these options at the ready constantly, you are truly only limited by your suits given power at the moment, your imagination and I suppose the edge of the map if you want to be that guy. The StoryIt's not going to win any awards, its certainly a big blockbuster summer movie thriller. But its got that primal visceral gumption to effectively pull at your heart strings and asks you to defend humanity from certain doom and annihilation during an alien invasion. A very, very minor spoiler warning; There are some very well done sequences involving the loss of power and the absence of heat that will really test your resourcefulness of the games mechanics. THE GISTOne of my favorite all time first person shooters that doesn't deserve the negative assertion of it being a tech demo it receive during the time of its initial release. It is far more than that and is still a lot better than some of the more modern shooters I've seen.Follow my curation for more

												Ahh Crysis, what a gem it is.If I look back to the early 2008 this was nearly a bomb for me; always wanted to play it, playing through and again, again, again.It holds itself up, after so many years, still looking good and still it is great fun. Mostly because of its Sandbox-like Gameplay. Fast first person shooter, or silent stealth game, or BOTH! Improvise or use tactic methods; weapon mods or the abillities of your armor. Get a vehicle, fill it with explosives and drive it into an enemy outpost, no problem. Throw your surrounding objects, like crates, barrels, refrigerators, chickens, at your enemies or destroy little houses. You can play as you like and the game doesn't punish you for it.I, for my part, didn't like they stealth gameplay though, it's quite hard if you really want to sneak through without an alarm going off. I like it more as an action game where most effort was put in.Besides your "one man- army" missions, you can take a seat in a tank battle, a helicopter escort mission or survive in an arctic world, fighting from fire to fire to keep yourself warm.It is great in every aspect of a game, not superior to most games today has to offer, but still...And a short word to the multiplayer:Although the GameSpy servers were shut down, it's still possible to play the multiplayer via a Mod created from the community.ConclusionRating: Very Good -> After all a wonderful shooter, varied, good-looking and just fun to play. Get this pearl, the price is just fair!

content:
3, 2014
												For a long time, I had Crysis down as a graphics demonstration; all the looks & headlines but with no substance. Hardly surprising when all that was talked about was 'Can it Crysis?'.However, I picked it up cheap in 2010 after building a fresh system & wanted to see what it could do.It was only when I found I was riveted to the game did I realise that underneither the headline grabbing garphics, was a game that utterly appealled to me; it's a seriously immersive story that holds on to you for hour after hour.The game play is excellent, switching suit modes is fast & intuitive, the gun upgrades are all worth considering & best of all you can be gung-ho if you want or you can stealth you way around & not really kill anyone & still acheive the mission objectives, the game simply sets you're objective, then lets you crack on with it, rather than forcing you one way or another, a trait that defines utterly iconic games like Deus-Ex.The vehicles handle like boats though, much like Farcry, Crytek's first game & the climax is a little overblown. It's dramatic & exciting, right up until you fight the final 'boss'. However, like Bioshock, the build up is so enjoyable, any final battle is going to feel like an anticlimax.Ultimately, the game ended with me chewing my hands for more, which means that it's succeeded in engrossing me in the world it's creating, which is the one thing I demand. An excellent multiplayer is all well & good, but if a game has a story line, in my mind, it has to stand on that alone or not at all. Crysis doesn't need the graphics or EA's massive marketing department to be a truly noteable game, but it does help make us aware of it.

content:
, 2016
~Maximum Review~This Action-FPS game was released back in November, 2007. But at the time it had some of the best graphics ever for a game of its kind! The main reason behind this was the kickass-German made Crytek engine that used a heavy demand on graphics cards at the time to present lots of new features. Does crytek sound familiar at all? if it does-that is because they also created the first far cry game waay back in 2004! 


Crysis 
A Screenshot of Crysis
By: Jaeger




These kinds of games typically have big expanses of various maps and consists of stealth missions near the start and middle sections but blooms into a beautiful action-set experience with lots of options! (Even some optional quests!). Crysis was no different and delivered a great action game with many new useful features/gameplay mechanics that more than made up for simpified story sequences, crappy nano-suit power (It is the damn future!) and some really dumb AI.Anyway i dont want to list everything this game offers here! instead ill chop it into clean little pieces and serve you....The Pros and Cons.Pros:+SO many awesome small little additions to gameplay that make a big difference! Some of these include: Your PC's battery level shown, lots more graphics and weapon options at the time, Minimap accuracy with coordinates,  enhanced physics and a deadly shark to stop people from leaving the map! A frickin shark!!+I really liked the Abilities FOR the nanosuit, but not the Nanosuit itself (Because of numerous energy reasons that ill describe in Cons below) The Cloak, Speed and Strength are used regularly, and for good reason!+The Story is very strong and warhead fits in very well. The Title really fits the plot! and the "Futuristic spelling" helps a little bit too i guess. No Purposeful emotional scenes or anything  like that, its an action game dammit! Shoot Cephs first and ask questions later!.But the story has got some great seperation between the stealth and action sequences! A calm cutscene to recap what big event just occured, followed by a guerilla-style trespass on an enemy base is a great mix! Basicsally what im trying to say is that the Pacing in this game is very well done. +The Vehicles some of which include: A tank, a Vtol jet, a Military jeep and military dinghyhandle very well surprisingly and are easy to control, speaking of that...+The tutorial is hardly a tuturial and just a slow part of the story that just happens to teach you the controls. Which are simple and very easy to change! (Loads of settings means more gameplay styles to suit more people=potential larger audience)+Map is big and cut into sections, but that doesnt really matter as you traverse most of the area with ease. Missions take you to several different locations some of which include: A Dense Tropical Forest, a Launch Site, Dig sites, Tank battleground (Large Clearing with airdrops) and even an Aircraft carrier! Dont classify this as an open world game at all! It is very linear like Basically all FPS shooters. It just has a big map for a few missions then changes it for a smaller, denser one And Repeats often.+Weapons are quite realistic and have noticeable effects with mixed with the nano-suits abilities! Bullpup rifles will have more recoil than the generic AK-47 found often and it will effect your aiming long distance!+The Way the Story transforms into the action packed shooter with various sci-fi elements attatched it amazing! If you asked me at the start of the game how i thought it would end, i would give a very different answer. But this is good! It means that the story will keep you guessing often while it introduces new Things to you.+I couldnt talk about the pros without mentioning the Graphics that it possesses, it is has lots of technical features that i could fill the list with but instead ill give you this  Link[dsogaming.com] Basically with mods it can run at 8k 60fps and all that good stuff. But remember this is extremely specific to most people. Depends if you care enough about it to mod the games really. But without it, it is definetely impressive+Enemies are difficult at times, and can be placed in such environments to even give some peope a fright!+Speaking of Difficulty...Try Delta! it really changes the game and makes you appreciate corners and baricades more than parts of the environment!


Standoff 
A Screenshot of Crysis
By: Jaeger




Cons:-Below-average boss battles, with repetitive strategies to defeat them. Especially at the end!Also i found myself restarting plenty of time because i didnt understand how to beat them clearly!-The AI in this game is quite dumb and found some soliders running into walls, ignoring me throwing grenades and even firing their guns randomly! (Who are they recruiting?).-The games "maps" are surprisingly linear as i said above and you are contantly reminded of this if you go slight too far away from the beach, or from a checkpoint, etc.-Nanosuit is so Underpowered. The features are great and well thought out, but due to the double A batteries of the suit most of the abilities run out after about 5-10 seconds! Running is definetely the worst offender, because it is one of the most useful mechanics in the game (And would have made speedrunning quite easy!) it is just sapped away by the energy so quickly! This might not seem too important to some people, but remember if you are in a fire-fight with enemies and you just used a different Ability (eg.Cloak-Mode) your energy will be sapped and if you need to make a inhumanly-quick escape...you can see where this is going.-Most of the Map is just jungle with beach attatched! it gets so boring after a little while and you always look for a car to drive quickly to the next location because you dont want to take a slow walk and "Enjoy" whats on offer. Because there really isnt much! although it may look very beautiful and all, it is not dense at all (Full with structures or unique features) much like Just Cause 1, 2 and 3! Although this is a linear shooter at the end of the day, it feels like in some sequences, its trying to awkwardly change that!-Lots of Glitches (Obviously! no game is perfect..) that affect the game's graphics and also a crappy save system which, although being very manual to the player, has a very irritating habit of saving before a big battle. Now what would happen if you arrived early to said battle and were already taking lots of damage? Maybe an explosion happens at the last second? Save System: "Go Back 30 mins  to the slow-stealth section please!"-Many minor parts of gameplay, controls or even visual effects will obviosuly be beaten by games today. So Ignorant players expecting a Battlefield 4 style Combat system will obviously not recieve it (The Combat/Weapon system and variety develops heavily in the second game!). Not really a Con, more of a "warning". But people know what they can expect now cant they!Final Thoughts:I give this game a 9/10! If you even remotely enjoyed Far Cry 1 or even 2, you will love the version with Aliens, futuristic weapons, and various Gameplay Tweaks.Highly Recommended for Anyone who likes FPS games in general, Expansive Areas and Sci-Fi Elements.


Whats next for Nomad? 
A Screenshot of Crysis
By: Jaeger

content:
ber 30, 2016
"But can it run Crysis?"While most PCs nowadays should be able to run the first Crysis game, it still engrained itself into the collective minds of gamers mainly because of its graphics and even today, 9 years after release, this game still looks great.  Because of its reputation as "playable graphics benchmark", I didn't go into this game expecting too much gameplaywise.  Fortunately enough, the game plays outstandingly, featuring open levels which most often allow for multiple approaches to nearly every situation.  The key gameplay mechanic is the so called "Nanosuit", which enables the protagonist to move at high speed, become invisible for a short time, gain super human strength or just be able to take more damage, transforming him into a one man army.  Despite these abilities, the player still has to choose his actions with care, for exposing himself to multiple enemies can still mean a quick death.  Due to this, the game remains challenging throughout the course of the adventure.The mission design is rich in diversity: apart from on-foot sections, the player is often able to use enemy trucks and boats to traverse the large playing areas, and may even pilot tanks and a VTOL aircraft over the course of the single player campaign.Unfortunately the game drops off towards its slightly unsatisfying conclusion, as it trades in its sandbox gameplay for more linear level design.Overall Crysis was a very fun experience due to the freedom given to the player and the options given by the Nanosuit.  While the story is by no means groudbreaking, the game is definitely worth picking up.

content:
17, 2016
CrysisBack when this game was first released, I remember how my PC at the time refused to even start it. Once I finally upgraded, I spent quite a few hours playing the demo, but I never ended up purchasing the full game. I noticed it on a Steam sale one day, and decided I'd finally finish the first-person shooter that gave me so many options, even with only one level.GraphicsWhen Crysis was first released, it was groundbreaking. It pushed every graphical limit known at the time, and the result was one of the most detailed and greatest looking first-person shooter games ever created. Post processing was used tastefully, almost every part of the environment is on the same high level of detail, and though some newer games have since left it in the dust, Crysis still holds up nicely, showing up games like Far Cry 3 or Arma 3 Apex thanks to the beautifully crafted levels of the Ling Shan islands. The only faults that Crysis has in the graphical department pertain to two vastly different ends of the spectrum. Terrain detail suffers the closer you get to the map boundaries, and character models - more specifically, face models - could definitely be better. With that said, if you want something nice to look at, Crysis will still give you that.


Crysis 
A Screenshot of Crysis
By: MorGun




AudioAudio design in Crysis is similarly high quality on most fronts. Weapons all sound punchy and satisfying, and the environmental effects are fantastic. The soundtrack, while not especially noteworthy, does contain some very nice orchestral tracks, and the game was scored well. The only major flaw with audio design is the voice acting and writing. The writing itself was like something out of a B-movie, and the voice acting quality matched it accordingly. One nice consolation about the voice acting is that all KPA troops will speak Korean on the highest difficulty level.PerformanceWhen this game was first released, it was often criticized for its performance. The question in many people's minds about PC gaming became, "Can it run Crysis? and often times, the answer would be no. But thankfully, as hardware has evolved, most people will have little trouble running this game now. My system runs Crysis on maximum settings and maintains a nice 60 frames per second at almost all times. There aren't many bugs that I've found, and although I did encounter a handful during my play-through, none of them were game-breaking.GameplayAt first glance, Crysis probably looks like a run-of-the-mill first-person shooter. Taking a deeper look reveals, however, what makes it so unique. The player is equipped with an experimental Nanosuit, a wonderful piece of technology that allows for them to switch into different enhanced modes: Maximum strength, speed, armor, or a cloaking system. This allows for situations to be tackled in almost any way imaginable, with either a focus on stealth and guerrilla tactics or pure shock and awe. There is also an on-the-fly weapon customization system, allowing the player to swap out attachments on every weapon to suit whatever situation they're faced with. This all leads to an immense amount of freedom in both single- and multiplayer environments, and is one of the things that makes Crysis so fun to play.


Crysis 
A Screenshot of Crysis
By: Vagabund




SingleplayerThe singleplayer campaign of Crysis places the player into the boots of Jake Dunn, a member of the futuristic Delta Force team Raptor, assigned to the Ling Shan islands in the Philippines. Raptor team was sent to locate an archaeologist who was taken hostage by task force of the Korean People's Army, though they soon discover there are far deadlier things at play than just the KPA forces on the ground. Each level is sequential and allows the player to carry over their items from the last, and each one presents the player with one goal or another, typically miles away from where they start. This means that the player is free to reach their objective however they want; some might opt to steal a vehicle and blast through KPA checkpoints, while others might stealthily creep through the jungle undetected. There are eleven levels in the campaign, each taking place in a different part of the islands, and the campaign itself will take most players between eight and twelve hours to complete, depending on the difficulty level and their tactics.MultiplayerThe multiplayer component of Crysis featured two primary gamemodes; Power Struggle and Instant Action. The latter was a run-of-the-mill deathmatch gamemode, made more unique by equipping every player with Nanosuits. The more unique and popular gamemode was Power Struggle, which at first glance resembled Conquest from the Battlefield series. The biggest divergence from Conquest was how a team would win; a specialized 'TAC' heavy tank would have to fire a tactical nuclear warhead at the other team's main base, obliterating it. Larger maps also featured factories in addition to normal objectives, which would produce vehicles over time, rather than simply spawning vehicles when an objective was controlled like in Battlefield. Unfortunately, I describe all of this in the past tense because the multiplayer was run through GameSpy, and Crysis did not receive a multiplayer patch after GameSpy shut down. As a result, there is, to my knowledge, no multiplayer community left in Crysis.


Crysis 
A Screenshot of Crysis
By: Stan




Community ContentCrysis redeems itself for its lackluster multiplayer component here. It features a terrain editor known as Sandbox which allows for the creation of both single- and multiplayer maps, and also supports user modifications. These modifications are unfortunately (mostly) limited to new weapons and vehicles, but you'll still probably be able to get a few more hours out of Crysis thanks to its support for community content.VerdictThe Crysis franchise is a bit of a tragic tale in my mind. The first game was so unique, and yet its developers threw away nearly all of what made it unique in favor of two scripted corridor shooter sequels which are, if you will, "all looks and no brains." Crysis certainly isn't a thinking man's game like the Arma series can be, but if you're looking an interesting and entertaining semi-open world first-person shooter and you see Crysis on sale, I would definitely endorse it.I would recommend Crysis, but would suggest waiting for a sale.

content:
13, 2016
												Now, don't let the age or tacky trailers fool you; Crysis, 9 years later, is still a phenomenal game that sent the industry forward. Imagine an FPS that removed most of the stupid cliches of modern FPS games, getting rid of things like "shotguns are short range" and "melee attacks deal 100x damage". When I first hopped into the game, I expected an FPS I would play for 3~ hours and say "eh, it was worth 4 dollars". What I got was a unique experience that left me with a constant desire to replay the game again and again,GAMEPLAY:Playing a tad like Far Cry (The developers started the series, featuring huge environment and gameplay similarities) or modern MGS, it allows you to approach enemies with a variety of ways with an INSANE ammount of ways to approach it. It isn't like Dishonored (Which I also highly reccomend) where every option feels forced and in your face; I can switch to Strength mode and knock down a hut, then use the curved roof as a ramp to launch myself out of danger by charging at it in speed mode. Encounter a 3 man patrol? pick up the strongest of the group, switch to strength mode, snap his neck and then toss him at another soldier, before finishing off the last one with a bullet to the head or a punch strong enough to instantly incapitate him. Base surrounded by trip mines? single individual guards out, toss them over the wall, and walk away as his body slides over the mines. Cornered by 4 men and using a box as cover? Switch to Strength mode, smash the box with the butt of a shotgun, then have the now flying box incapitate them all. Small radio station on a hill? lure the opposition into a frail building then smash the roof, causing the building to collapse and kill everyone inside. Taking the high ground to scout is beneficial, as in one situation I spotted a car 'bout half a mile off speeding down the road, allowing me to take the chance to shoot out its tires from a long distance, causing the speeding vehicle to go spiraling into a ditch, killing the crew inside. While scouting, I spotted an attack boat surverying a cargo loading zone. As the boat went further down shore, I dove to the bottom of the seabed. As the boat made its approach, I switched to speed mode and swam upward at superhuman speed, sending me a good 20~ feet out of the water... and allowing me to toss a grenade stright into the boat. Armored patrol of 5 getting out of a car? Strength mode, jump to one side, kill the two koreans and shoot the gunner atop the car, then punch the car hard enough to send it spiraling into the remaining Koreans. Catch a DISGUSTING COMMUNIST taking a leak (Enemies actually do this) at a river? hold him underwater until he drowns.Needless to say, the game is packed with variety, and even without it, the gunplay, which is phenomenally realistic and enjoyable, would alone make the game worth it.STORY:A bit generic on the outside (Crysis 2 and 3 aren't as good but expanded on the story quite well), Crysis' story is quite good, but certainly not the best feature of the game. SPOILERS AHEAD; Technologically advanced Aliens nicknamed the Ceph are advanced to the point of being able to create anything they can think of; so, they turn their minds to things they cannot think of or predict. They send "Colonization pods" to planets that have the potential to host life, with our world being Pod-ed two-million years before Humanity came to exist. In 1912, Richard Hargreave sets out on an expedition with 3 other individuals to Alaska, where there is rumored "riches". What he and his crew discover, however, is a massive ammount of Ceph Technology. Hargreave's two colleagues are heavily injured in the operation, and using alien tech, he saves their lives with reported super-human abilities. Hargreave, being a genius, founds Hargreave Science Corp, and begins to use Ceph technology to create weapontry and amass a fortune. Sometime between 1990 and 2200, Hargreave begins to fear a Ceph awakening and allies Hargreave Science Corp. and the child company Crynet Systems (Hence why "Crysis" is spelt the way it is) with the United States, giving them acess to Nano-Suit technology.  North Korea discovers and alien colonization pod on the Lang Shian Islands and mobilizes the North Korean People's Army to evacuate the island with the intention of utilizing Alien technology to become most advanced civilization and to defeat the United States. However, their intentions are never fufilled, as two elite Nanosuit teams (Team Raptor, Crysis 1, and Team Eagle, Crysis Warhead) defeat massive ammounts of Korean People Army Forces, and combined with the awakening of the Ceph colonization pod, which the main charecter of Crysis 1, Nomad, enters in an attempt to defeat the Ceph. Realizing his efforts are futile, he attempts to escape the pod, only to be met with a Frozen Wasteland created by the Ceph in an attempt to push out human forces. Nomad, Psycho, and Prophet (Nanosuited Individuals) escape the frozen landscape and rejoin eachother on a U.S Battleship, where Nomad is provided an experimental tactical nuke device, and also where the Captain of the ship fails to realize that Ceph absorb energy, foolishly launching a massive nuclear missle into the massive, frozen dome, causing it to massively expand and to trigger the full force of the Ceph invasion. The Ceph assault the ship, and after defeating a massive alien monster called "The Hunter", the ship is attacked by a gigantic alien battleship, witch sinks the ship and is barely defeated by Nomad. This "Victory" is only a small one in a massive war, with more to come in Crysis 2 and 3 (Honestly, just read about the lore. The games are pretty bad and ruined any chance of the series being any good once more)I hope you've enjoyed my lengthy review. Crysis is easily one of my favorite games of all time, if not THE favorite (Next to New Vegas <3). I'm sure you'll enjoy the game, here are some mods I reccomend;Blackfire's Mod Ultimate OR CyberAlien's Extreme Immersive modAdvanced AIRealistic EnhancementRygels HD Texture pack AND HD Crysis Texture Pack 2016Maximum ImmersionCrysis 2 Nanosuit Voice (Crysis 2 did a lot of things wrong but the suit was awesome)Enjoy the game!nominate for farm or test of time award

content:
10, 2016
												Crysis was a very good game and the first in a great series developed by Crytek and published by Electronic Arts in 2007. Crysis is a science-fiction first person shooter. You, the player, play as Nomad, an exceptional and strong-willed character determined to fight to survive. The game is primarily set on a North-Korean controlled island where they are attempting to uncover the mystery of a potential grand discovery. Nomad and his nano-suited military team mates and the United States army intervene, however the reveal of a greater power, named the Ceph, strongly influences and alters the story.This campaign is excellent. The campaign is a great example of a story that starts slow, but builds to a climax. The setting of being on one island suggests a limited campaign, however, the great areas of on the island and in the island create a nice variety of missions. I adore the fluidity and transition between missions within the campaign. For instance, you complete a mission and run to the extraction point - instead of the game taking you to a loading screen, it immediately starts the next mission, which is a massive positive. The only issue I encountered with the campaign is the mild relevance of the side missions. Nomad would have to gain intel from a North Korean camp, and while it adds some further dialogue in the story, it is not substantial. Also, it is really a standalone player game as your squad-members do not assist you in missions and are very useless.Gameplay is your standard first person shooter gameplay, The gameplay is fluid and solid. There is nothing more to elaborate on regarding shooting and cover. Driving is a nice feature but clunky as the vehicle is very sensitive to player controls. The issues I encountered within the gameplay section is the lack of ammo for an American gun and the very small variety of overall guns in the game. I had to rely on a North Korean assault rifle because there was no ammo to be found for my American Scar. There are some minor bugs such as the red dot on a red dot sight not appearing and the insane amount of bullets required to kill an armoured North Korean enemy. To kill an enemy would regularly take 75% of a magazine. To kill an Alien would take a larger amount of ammo, which is understandable as they are strong aliens, but for humans, that is very odd. The main disturbance regarding gameplay is the sheer stupidty of AI. Some enemies would run in circles while ally team mates would be useless in completing objectives, as stated prior.The graphics are incredible for a game developed in 2007. Crytek is known as a high-quality graphical company and they really emphasised that in Crysis. While the recommended settings were a Nvidia GT 8800, I could not play at ultra settings, even with my graphics card, which is odd as I had to play on very high settings with V Sync and Anti Aliasing turned off.Overall, this game is a good game. I only played the campaign and I can safely say I thoroughly enjoyed the experience. I played this game in around eight hours. It's a solid length of a game. I recommend the game at the Steam price of $19.99. Furthermore, I would strongly suggest buying the Maximum Edition that includes Crysis, Crysis: Warhead, and Crysis II. Three aspects in review:Campaign: 9/10Gameplay: 7.25/10Graphics: 8/10Overall: 8.25/10Thanks for reading my review! If you like my reviews and care to read more, feel free to join Antwog's Analysis (Reviews). http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviews

ry 23, 2014
												This review is for the game ''Crysis'',a first-person shooter video game,developed by the video game company Crytek.The game was published by Electronic Arts and released in November 13 on 2007(in North America) for Microsoft Windows.The game uses the CryEngine 2 and was later upgraded to CryEngine 3(not for Microsoft Windows though).PlotYou are Nomad,a delta force soldier,who with the use of his military nanosuit's capabilities (Maximum Strength,Maximum Speed,Maxim Armor and Cloak) his weapons,vehicles and with his other military friends and along the way acquaintances has to engage enemies(firstly Koreans then bloodthirst aliens) in order to save the world from the possible alien domination.Gameplay:The player can  encounter enemies in a variety of ways.You can use short ranged weapons or ranged rifles,use stealth and surprise your enemies by attacking them from behind(either killing them swiftly or tranquilizing them) or just aggressivly kill whatever moves by spraying bullets all over their bodies.Game includes a high variety of weapons such as:pistols,assault rifles,sub-machine guns,missile launchers,gauss rifles,shotguns,miniguns,the TAC gun and the MOAC all of which can be customized through several attachments like the sniper scope,the iron sight scope etc.In addition you can usemany vehicles like hovercrafts,jeeps,acp,vtol etcMultiplayer: Even if this game is 7 years old you'll be surprise to see how many people still play crysis 1RecapThis game is a must buy.Incredible graphics(remember the phrase "Yeah, but can it run Crysis?"),Simple yet enjoyable story-some would say Cliché but not me(Bad Koreans have found an energy resource and they want to use it but everything goes to hell and aliens swarms the island BUT a brave American saves the day with his raw masculinity,risks his life and saves the day alongside his trusted companions.),Challenging gameplay,Atmospheric gameplay and many many other characteristics that make this game a piece of fine art.Only thing i find as a con is the customization which i found limited.Can easily compete with modern 2014 games in many ways and win.Thank you Crytek Developers for this wonderful game.P.S I didn't refer much on the Plot section because i didn't want to spoil the game to you.Buy it and play it thoroughly.You can thank me later.

content:
er 31, 2013
 Originally posted on January 21, 2010 Crysis is an absolutely incredible experience that defines why PC gaming is great. It's an open world shooter with graphics that are 2.5 years old and are still by far the most impressive offering on the market. It's gameplay is a varied hybrid of stealth and action in the proud tradition of Far Cry one, and although there are a few problems with the game, it is one you should not miss if you own a PC.Gameplay-As in it's spiritual successor, Far Cry, Crysis is a game that centers around island/tropics based combat in an open world with lots of vehicles and baddies with great AI that can use vehicles, flank, retreat, give orders, and call in unscripted backup. You hit multiple objectives using stealth or assault tactics and a wide variety of weapons.This much has not changed very much from Far Cry, and I see no problem with that. The AI very much Far Cry 1.5 AI, which is impressive considering Far Cry AI still tops many games on the market. Enemy vehicles still chase you relentlessly once you are discovered, and harder levels can be particularly brutal. You are not usually accompanied by many friendlies in a helpful manner, but there are certain fixed engagements where you encounter friendly AI, and they get the job done decently. It remains a lone-wolf experience for the majority of the game.The most major change comes in the form of the nano-suit, which allows speed, jumping/punching, and armor to rise to greater levels at the expense of energy, and the suit includes a cloaking device. This simple mechanic allows for a huge amount of fun to be had, especially in jungle infantry combat and in enemy camps.Another change would be the addition of on the fly weapon customization, a brilliant addition, and the ability to pick up attachments as you progress through the game. I will say that as gamers we do not always stop to examine the model of each weapon lying on the ground or even in an armory and as a result miss out on early instances of great attachments, such as the sniper scope. Could the auto-ammo-pick-up system from warhead be included in the next installment with a feature that picks up attachments you don't have as well? That would be wonderful. Also, the ability to suppress certain weapons would be welcome and not altogether unbalanced or "unrealistic". I could envision the shotgun and sniper rifle being suppressed but with a louder sound signature and working in game just fine.I will say the alien gameplay is a little less fun, as it was with mutants in far cry, and though the story remains interesting, the enemies are somewhat less interesting to fight (warhead partially helps with this) due to less intelligent tactics and repetitive attacks. Also, the introduction of Aliens generally is accompanied by more linear missions, which is not where this type of game shines. Far Cry had the same problem.Story- However, far cry also had a terrible story, with about as much cheese as anyone can handle. Crysis' story actually is quite decent, and they really take advantage of some cool cinematic techniques to tell it. The plot certainly makes more sense than Avatar's, and the pacing is better too. And what Avatar's technical visuals are for movies, Crysis' are for games.Visuals- Crysis is currently(Jan. 2010) the best looking game on the market for any gaming platform, and will most likely continue to stay there until Crysis 2. This has been the situation since Crysis was released in 2007! This gap is of course due largely to the economic impact of console markets and in turn the technical limitations of consoles, and Crysis really demonstrates this gap. The last great PC exclusive graphics engine, in all honesty. Not to mention that after patching and drivers it is quite well optimized, and though I must admit I have a 4870, it runs well on much worse hardware. The Character models and lighting effects are standouts in the visuals category, accompanied by the water and foliage effects. The alien ship also looks astounding.Also, the music is cinematic and the battle theme is really quite exceptional.All in all, Crysis is a graphics juggernaut that nothing on the market can really touch, and incredible shooter and gaming experience, and not a half bad-cinematic experience either (certainly better than any big-budget Michael Bay style film I've ever seen). This comes together in one amazing package that meets all expectations as far as I'm concerned, even if it could have improved in a few areas.

content:
2
 Disclaimer This review is aimed at the single player portion of the game. Detail I first played this game back in 2007. It was the talk of the town, all because of it's advanced CryEngine I was so impressed that my Pentium Dual Core processor, 4GB RAM and my trusty Radeon 2600XT could run this on medium. I simply watched in awe of the images which were rendered before me. Since then I always used this as one of my go to benchmark games and tools - upgraded to an Intel Core 2 Quad Q8200 and NVIDIA 9800 GT and later to my previous rig: i7 870, 8GB RAM, and Radeon 5870. I could finally play this game smoothly on ultra at 1920 x 1080. It looked stunning.But, apart from the graphics department, how good is this game really?The plot is a mixed bag. It's no different from your typical action movie, but not bad either. I really didn't care about any of the characters, except for Psycho and prophet. Nomad (controlled by the player) has a stale personality, almost robot-like and emotionless, focussing only on the mission at hand. Crytek tried a few times to give the idea of emotion, but ultimately it still felt shallow.The game mechanics are very fluent. Movement and gunplay feels natural and faced paced – exactly what you want in a shooter. The Nano suit was a great new innovative idea, breathing new life into the generic state shooters usually are.The campaign maps are huge. The environments are unique, varying from lush jungles to dirt filled excavation sites.One major issue for me was optimization. Bear in mind that there came a point in time where Crysis reached it's limitation at fully utilization modern hardware. It was unable to fully utilise both my CPU and GPU – the CPU cores sometimes only being used between 20% and 40%. The GPU had similar results. There were a few scenes which the frames dropped below 60fps toward 20 to 30 fps, although it kept to 60 fps 95% of the time. This is an older game which was released when Core 2 Duo CPU’s were the gaming standard and the 9800 GTX was the cream of the crop. To expect that it should fully utilise modern hardware is ridiculous, but something to take note of. Verdict  The good  Beautiful graphics and environments. Huge open ended maps. Good game mechanics. The bad  Boring, unimaginative and forgettable characters. Unoptimized for modern hardware. Occasional frame drops.Overall, it’s a great game which I highly recommend. All PC gamers should pick this one up.

content:
er 23, 2012
												Crysis offers standard FPS gameplay with a twist: a combat suit that effectively lets you choose your gameplay mode. Your suit can dial up different abilities: Choose the "Shield" setting if you want to run into combat guns-a-blazin', choose the "Speed" option if you need to outrun pursuing opponents, or choose a cloaking option if you're pinned down and need to sneak away. Much like the Spy's cloak in TF2, Crysis' cloak doesn't last long enough to engage in real stealth missions, this most noticable absence.A suit setting for "strength" that lets you, um, jump high (?) becomes a way to solve environmental puzzles, like how to scale a cliff. (Hint: look for the rock outcroppings that look like tall stairs. There's always one nearby.)I like this open-endedness. You are rewarded for finding a location to survey the road ahead and plan an attack. Disregard the voice in your ear telling you how important it is that you move along urgently.But I generally did not enjoy the gameplay. Run a bit, fight a bit. Run a bit, fight a bit. It gets old quickly. And it's the kind of game that forces you to scour for ammo, and constantly re-choose between several types of rifles, based on what the enemies around you are using. Me? I prefer the Half-Life model where you just bring every gun along and collect ammo as you walk near to it. Requiring any more effort that that feels like unpleasant work, and it bogs this game down.The story is disposable, and I never felt attached to the events of the game. The AI is good, and very aggressive.But let's be honest. The appeal of Crysis in 2007 was the then-fantastic graphics. The game still looks good in 2012, but it's far from cutting edge, today. Take away the graphics and you're left with a so-so shooter. Proceed accordingly.
