ber 11, 2016
												The first part of this game on the highest difficulty is simply perfection. You are an elite Spec Ops warrior having to regroup with your team on a tropical island amid a heavy North Korean military presence. You have to use precise stealth and stalking  tactics to stay alive and take down soldiers. Yes you have a nano-suit but it will not keep you alive in a fire-fight against a platoon of enemies. The story is tense and builds up nicely to a confrontation between North Korean and American troops. And the visuals are still, 10 years later, maybe the best ever created if you have the hardware. Then... suddenly it becomes an aliens game and it loses alot of its edge towards the end, before a thrilling final fight. 9.5/10 Still a legendary FPS and better than the uninspiring sequels.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ber 24, 2016
												If you , like me, were here to see if your latest PC could run Crysis maxed out and still hold a decent frame rate... I have bad news for you. It can't. But, do not dispair... After all these years I can look back, wisened in my old age, and realise that Crysis was never going to run well. The developers were using so many new, unrefined graphics techniques that the game by its very nature is not capable of running at a steady 60FPS, with all the graphics turned up to very high. And it never will be capable of holding a steady 60FPS. Guys, Crysis just runs badly. I'm afraid that's the hard truth we all have to swallow....Quick tip; if you find the frames chugging, just turn off, or turn down, the very bizarre motion blur effect. It murders the FPS, and really doesn't look especially good. Strange, no matter how fast I whip my head around I just can't seem to make the world blur like that....  But now that we've got that out of the way, does the game still hold up after all these years? Does it still look good, and is it still a good game? Good news; yes.Upon first starting Crysis my jaw landed somewhere between my nipples. It really is incredibly difficult to believe this game is nearly ten years old. And, it's equally mind blowing to realise just how much the Xbox360 and PS3 held back graphics advancements, considering where they were prior to console restrictions. In some areas of Crysis the foliage and lighting effects are still mind blowingly good, even by modern standards. Sure, the rock textures are vomit inducing, and the tree trunks look like the rear end of a horse, but the overall foliage detail is still extremely impressive. I just never get tired of shooting through foliage and seeing the physics effects.Gameplay wise I can only say this; "Oh, yeah. So this is what games were like before the CoD generation."You can lean! And go prone! You can change the fire mode of your gun! You can throw chickens at enemies! (Here's a challenge for you; see how far you can get in the game by murdering people only with thrown wildlife.)The enemies in Crysis really don't ♥♥♥♥♥ foot around, especially on harder difficulty settings. And frankly, I love it. Once they've spotted you they will murder your ♥♥♥. Its genuinely challenging, and the nano suit is actually REQUIRED, or you will get your brains handed to you in five seconds flat. I haven't played a game that offers such wide open spaces, with such a feeling of freedom and realism, in a very long time. Crysis 3 is equally as challenging, as I recall, but just doesn't deliver the same feeling of space that Crysis 1 does. Crysis 1 feels like a real island, and although some may say the space is wasted, I say it does exactly what it's meant to; make you feel like you're in a real world situation.  In conclusion; Crysis is still pretty impressive as far as graphics go, but the real surprise for me was to realise just how good a game it still is. I strongly suggest giving it a go again, especially if you're an 80's baby like myself. Take a dip back into the good old days of first person shooters, folks, you'll be pleasantly surprised.

												Crysis 1 could have been a masterpiece at its time, yet it ended up being merely an unpolished one. Still, this game should be played by FPS fans at least once since the first half of the game is pretty good.+ It looked well in 2007 and it's still very good looking+ Great first half of the game+ A lot of open world missions. How do you want to proceed with your mission is totally up to you. You can just shoot them all, use your stealth cloak or often simply avoid all enemies.+ This series has some of the best soundtracks.+ A lot of weapons to choose from. Also, you can modify them if you want to.- Optimization is bad and it was that way even upon release. Some players might find the game impossible to run on very high settings despite having a modern pc.- The second half of the game felt a bit weak in comparison.- This game is quite inbalanced at times. Some parts are rather easy while others will have you killed by hordes of bullet sponge enemies. - One specific alien mission was rather long and boring. I got lost and was more confused than entertained. - Note that there is a bug in the second last mission where you have to fly to a carrier that will lead to a CTD. Quicksaving at the very same moment when a soldier called Psycho muttered his last sentence before quickloading let me continue playing the game and solved this bug for me.It somehow felt like playing an independence day game. I recommend buying the crysis collection if it's on sale. If you like FPS, Crysis 1 is certainly worth checking out.Replay value: AverageRating: 8/10Recommendation: Yes

content:
13, 2015
												I only got round to playing Crysis in 2015, although I've been meaning to for years!From what I'd seen, I was under the impression that you'd play a kind of semi-indestructable super soldier in this game, dashing and jumping around at high speed and slicing through dozens of enemy soldiers with ease, but really it plays more like you're just a fairly standard FPS soldier dude with a few perks. I found myself not bothering with things like the stealth and speed mode very often as they both drain your energy incredibly quickly. On hard difficulty, a few well-placed enemy bullets can still take you down if you're not careful so you don't really feel invulnerable.The gameplay is fairly standard FPS fare, akin to Call Of Duty or whatever, with open-ish world elements but lots of set pieces. The game world never feels as open as, say, the Far Cry series and you are pretty much railroaded into tackling things in order, though how you approach each set piece is up to you and you do feel that you can take a variety of approaches to solve the obstacles you encounter.The graphics have really stood the test of time, It didn't feel particularly dated.My only gripe was that the campaign only took me 10 hours to play through - and I didn't exactly rush through it. If I'm honest, the storyline is also very standard and unengaging, following a rather cliched 'US saves the world from alien invasion that is unwittingly aided by the nasty Asians' formula that's all too familiar by now.Overall, I'd say that if you're a fan of the FPS genre, you've never played Crysis before and you see if on sale for a few pounds/dollars (like I did) then it's definitely worth picking up! It's an enjoyable, if short, experience.

												Crysis was a game that changed PC gaming in significant ways.  Release in 2007 the game is still fun, relevant, and beatiful all the years later (2014).  ** GRAPHICS **I just now have a computer that can run it with everything turned to max settings (1080p) and it is as good looking as most games being released now.  Many people say it requires a beefy machine because it is poorly optimized but I argue that even if that is the case, it still looks great!  The engine this game was built on has gone on to provide great graphics in many other games as well.** GAME PLAY **Crysis added a fun element to the game with temporary "super powers".  Managing your super human suit abilities allowed a variety of game play not traditionally found in the FPS genre at the time of its release.  The game is good.  Its fun to play and to look at.** Summary **If you don't have it yet it is absolutely worth picking up at its bargain price.  It is a great FPS to sit down and play for a short stint or marathon with.  I highly recommend it.

Anything else, you can consider it broken.Enemies become virtually omnipotent whenever they're on a mounted gun, with an unlimited spotting distance. This is a sign of pure incompetence, a failure to grasp multiple important concepts of game design. You don't need to look bad to play bad. You can scuplt a Michelangelo piece out of faeces, but what do you still have?Crysis. That's what. Don't waste your time unless you're just out to prove your PC's power.

content:
er 26, 2016
												1st 2/3 of the game was fun. Open world, you chose how to fight. Lush, living world that is inviting you to explore it. I really did like this part of the game as it was very engaging. Graphics still look pretty awesome despite the fact the game was released so long ago. Combat system felt very fluid as you can use anything as a weapon basically -  You can use enemy soldiers as bowling balls, drown them, toss them off a cliff, club them, get into a fist fight, hit them with trucks or boats and more.The world itself is very interactive as you can pick up and throw chickens, local wildlife, rock, branches, pots, fruits, barrels and much more to slam the enemy with. Entire trees will topple over in heavy gun / grenade fire. Soft targets such as huts can be completly destroyed by gunfire / grenades, ramming, or tossing enemy soldiers though the walls.Desite all the good this game has to offer, I do have a couple gripes though that really detracted from my overall experience.1 - Enemies shrug of rediculous amount of damage. I can shoot a guy in the knee - He still manages to sprint as if nothing happened. I can shoot a guy in the head...oh wait he's wearing a basebal cap that allows him to tank 3-4 hits from an assault rifle. What? Enemies really should be more responsive to damage, especially when shot in unprotected areas....like the face...or the balls. Not moving at either 100% or dead.2 - Enemies movement can be unrealisicaly rediculous. Dancing side to side  in the open to dodge bullets, tanking and strafing. I'm not a fan of this in any shooter. With a game that looks as realistic as crysis, I expected different.3 - The last 1/3 of the game - Punishment. What happened? This here was the real turnoff for me - The game turned into a generic, boring rail shooter with extremely, useless, needy, comrade AI that curses you out left and right for not moving fast enough. Your character turns into a yes man that just runs around, taking orders from everyone to do every single thing. Story also falls apart and generally by this point in the campain I really found it increasingly difficult to care...I just wanted it to end as it just got so boring. The alien AI requires no tactics to fight as their combat manuvers are pretty much limited to strafing you from range, or charge in and slash you. With the earlier part of the game playing so well, I'm not sure why they would go this route - by the end the game is nothing like how it started, it feels very cramped and controlled. TLDR - The 1st 2/3's of the game is fun and well done. The Last acts, not worth my time - The game devolved into a heavily scripted, cramped railshooter. At the end....I'm kind of neutral on this one. Now if only we had a button that wasn't thumbs up or thumbs down....

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
11, 2014
												Crysis. Oh dear Crysis. It's the fabled representative of the "PC master race" cause. Is it a good game? Well, lets see. The story is a bit cliched, reeking of "Humanity screwed around with something they shouldn't have" trope, but it is handled with a bit of creativity. You are Nomad, a member of Raptor team, an elite group of soldiers for the U.S Military. It's 2020, and you and you're team are dispatched to rescue some hostages from the Korean People's Army. The hostages were apparantly scientists and archaeologists who had found something buried in the biggest mountain in the area. So, you initally get seperated from your team, and one of your squadmates who barely has any character gets killed off screen by something who "Tore his body up bad". From there, you trek you're way across the island you're set on, killing wave after wave of KPA troops. You learn a fanatical general, General Kyong, is in charge of the Korean Military occupation of the island, and you find one of the hostages. Then you start to get a sense that something else is on this island with you. Something inhuman. Raptor team's leader, Prophet, gets kidnapped by the same thing that killed your other squadmate in the opening, and you eventually get to General Kyong in a rather anticlimatic boss fight, ending with learning that yes. Aliens are in fact real, and that they really love the cold. From there, it just devolves to "Stop the Aliens from taking over the world." I say the story is cliched, sure, but it has it's moments. The voice acting is top notch, with at least some of the actors caring for their roles. Sure, almost all of Raptor team seems to be full of racial and cultural stereotypes, but they grow on you after a while. Heck, Psycho, the british personality, got so popular he even got his own spin-off game, but i'll get to that another time. As for your character, Nomad, he's a little bland. He hardly says anything, as per the first person shooter method, but dare I say, even Master Chief from the Halo series has more character than him. He just seems like the standard, military type who's honorable, and tough. And thats about it. All in all, it's an okay sci-fi plot. Nothing too new brought to the table, but not terrible.The gameplay is pretty damn solid. The biggest table-turner and innovation you have in the game, is the Nanosuit. Imagine if  Master Chief's suit got a major upgrade. Like, major. Actually, imagine this. Imagine if Master Chief's suit, got the abilities of Flash, The Predator, and Hulk. Thats the Nanosuit in a nutshell. It has four distinct modes to choose from. Strength, Speed, Cloak, and Armor. You can only use one at a time, but changing them up on the fly will help you win many, many battles. The Cloak is a little abusive, but thats what Delta level difficulty is for, where the enemy will often see your little invisibility trick. Armor mode is also another one thats pretty abusive, but it does make combat so much easier. Speaking of combat, the firefights in this game are pretty intense sometimes. You do have a somewhat limited arsenal. Theres no carrying around ten different kinds of guns like Duke Nukem 3D or Half Life, but it's no two weapon limit either. You get two primary weapons, two pistols, ten grenades, a heavy weapon like an RPG, C4 charges, and your bare hands. The primary weapon variety in this game is diverse, with 3 kinds of machine guns, and a few others I won't spoil here. Almost every weapon has customization options, like different kinds of scopes, or laser sights. Now, about your enemies. Don't think for a second, that just because the KPA are made entirely of a rather low tech militia, that they aren't dangerous. Each and every one of them can and will kill you without a thought. The A.I that drives them is also nice to watch. While they sometimes do goofy things, like stare at walls, and shout that they are throwing a grenade, but the grenade never comes, they sometimes do rather intelligent things, like flank you, take cover in the bushes, and converge on you from all different angles. The manner in which you take on the numerous amount of KPA infantry is also pretty expansive. Do you go in, all guns blazing, tearing and blowing everything up in sight? Or do you prefer to be the human equivalent of the Predator, sneaking in and taking them out one by one? The choice is yours. Theres also a fair amount of vehicular combat as well, but these vary in the fun factor. For example, the section where you blast your way through a valley in a tank is beyond the term awesome, but other sections like the VTOL retreat, just feel a bit broken, especially in control. Oh, and then theres the latter half of the game. With the aliens. Once you leave the mountain halfway through the game, say bye bye to diverse tactics and combat options, and say hello to generic "Just use a really BFG to kill them!". Seriously, the alien combat is the dullest and most boring thing I experienced with this game. There is no specific weakness to exploit with the aliens, just fill them full of projectiles until they crash and burn. To poorly balance this, the final boss of the game, has easily exploitable weaknesses, that make the fight over in less than ten minutes. Overall, I say that Crysis's gameplay is fun as all gets out, until the second you beat General Kyong, and then it all goes downhill from there. Thats just my opinion however. The multiplayer, on the other hand, well...I heard it was fun when people actually played it. The Power Struggle gametype seems like a creative idea, outright destroying the enemy team's base? Sounds pretty awesome to me.In terms of graphics, yes, Crysis is pretty to look at. The world is very detailed, and realistic. However, I promise you, that you'll be spending about twenty minutes in the settings of the game, tweaking and testing, until you get it to look exactly how you want it to look. Once you do though, you'll wonder how this was a game made in 2007, with it's vibrant colors, detailed textures, realistic physics, and excellent sound design. Also, the soundtrack by Inon Zur is amazing, with flourishes coinciding with whats going on around you.Overall, for it's okay story, pretty fun gameplay, and it's nice-to-look-at graphics, I give Crysis a 6/10. It's a must have for any fan of the first-person-shooter genre, and I highly reccommend it.

content:
ry 14, 2013
												"Can your computer run Crysis?"Despite the fact that it has been many years since Crysis came out, you still hear this every once in a while (usually in jest). I definitely wasn't worried about my GTX 670 and i5-3750k having trouble.I had psyched myself up about the visuals so much that my initial impression was "well this doesn't look half bad..." and then I remembered how old the game is. And I nearly peed myself. Even the cutscenes were rendered in the game engine, so the game always had a consistent visual style.The appeal for anybody who plays Crysis is of course the beautiful graphics, so I wasn't expecting much from the story or gameplay. As it turns out the gameplay was really good; the controls were nice and tight, even when you drive vehicles. Even flying a VTOL (those flying things that work like helicopters) and floating around in zero-gravity was intuitive, which is saying a lot.Although Crysis is obviously a linear game, the map was usually open enough that as long as you are going in the general direction of your next objective (which is what your character, Nomad, would be doing anyway) you won't feel constrained at all.The one area where gameplay suffered was the enemy AI. I found them laughably stupid, and took great sadistic pleasure in luring large numbers of them into small choke points where I could easily mow them down.On the opposite end of the spectrum, there were a couple of areas where I really wasn't given sufficient tools to complete the objectives. One example was a map where I was trying to destroy a few anti-aircraft emplacements. I ended up having two enemy helicopters following me around, and I only found one rocket launcher on the entire map. It was a pretty open map so I may have missed the others, but they weren't in any of the obvious places. So I ended up just running around cloaked as much as possible until I managed to complete my objective. Oh, and once that was complete the helicopters magically went away.The nano suit is the biggest aspect of the game (besides the graphics) that differentiates Crysis from other military shooters. The suit allows you to choose between several modes: strength, speed, armor, and cloak. Thanks to the nano suit you can play the game using a variety of play styles. One of my favorite things to do was to sneak into a complex cloaked dual-wielding a couple of silenced pistols with laser sights. It then became a nice little exercise in shooting everyone in the head one at a time before they figured out that I was there (and given that the AI was so stupid they would only figure out that I was there if they got a nice long look at me while uncloaked.) Ninja Nomad.The story can be summed up pretty quickly: North Koreans and aliens on a tropical island.Once you know that, nothing will surprise you. There were no plot twists, no sudden betrayals or finding out someone was a double agent or anything. But I was fine with that, because that wasn't why I was there anyway. That being said, I did like the ending; it was a satisfying "hell yeah!" at the end of a nice ten-hour campaign.If you are at all interested in playing Crysis, now is the best time to do it. The game is old enough that it is really cheap but it is still new enough to look good.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 18, 2012
												Crysis has had a strange life since it's release in 2007. At the time of it's release it was by far the most technologically challenging game to play, utilizing graphics that would make even the high end PC's of the time scream in terror. Because of this simple fact it was for the longest time mentioned in conversation much as one would mention a benchmark tool and throughout gaming, that is how it was viewed. A measure of the strength of your PC. A strange fate for a game.Although there has never been much concern for the game beneath the graphics Crysis isn't a bad game. Although it does nothing new or revolutionary it is a good solid FPS that is spared the horrors of knee high walls that often afflicts other games in this genre.You play as a super soldier wearing the Crytek version of power armor, a skintight bodysuit that lets you active various temporary abilities such as invisibility and bullet absorption. Although the attempt at stealth is fairly half-hearted the ability to leap 20 feet into the air and jump 60 miles per hour allows you to engage enemies in a variety of ways and that certainly helps keep the gunplay fresh.The storyline is fairly standard, supersoldier stuff and the voice-acting doesn't go completely bad despite some poorly casted movie stars as your supporting cast.All in all it's a fun play although not a game I think would have ever been made much noise about if it wasn't for the incredible graphics.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
y 29
Product received for free
												The game to melt your rig. Well, not anymore, but it still holds a level of graphical fidelity that even today puts many recently released games to shame. Not to mention that with an abundance of mods, due to the rather open nature of the game's engine, you can make it look better than ever.The game itself is a solid shooter, an in certain regards even a really good one. Fighting the KPA on higher difficulties (with the enemies speaking Korean and no crosshair) can get really intense. And that's also the greatest thing about the game: Without being an open world game, you have all the freedom you can imagine to reach your target. Do you sneak through enemy lines? Try to find an unused path? Do you steal a vehicle? Even tanks may not be safe from you. Get the job done YOUR way! You want to do the tank mission on foot? JUST DO IT! The game rarely limits you in what you can do and what you should do.This changes later on, when suddenly the game introduces a new set of enemies and gameplay rules. To keep it fresh, the game uses truly three dimension gameplay, although that doesn't help covering up the fact that lush open jungle with wide areas are exchanged for small, almost corridor-like levels that don't allow for the same freedom as before.If you want more, the community got you covered: There is an unimaginable amount of mods of all kinds available, from simple texture jobs to highlights like Chrjs "Rainy Days", which reaches a whole new level of "WOW!" with intelligent companion AI (significantly better than what even Crysis Warhead offers in that regard) and excellent voice acting - and all that for free. You can of course get your own hands muddy, and dive right into the extremely easy to use "Editor" to create your own settings and missions (or just modify the maps of the single player levels to freeze every single Korean soldier with your God given freeze gun).

content:
ber 7, 2016
												(Finished the game)I love the way crysis is from such a first-person view that it makes it seem so real. For example when your player is in the alien-world the game limits you from knowing anything about what is going on outside, instead of letting you know everything and making it seem like you are some god looking down and seeing everything going on. This means that the game sort of sweeps by; one minute you are on your own on an island, the next the US army suddenly turn up, and your character gets tossed around, straight in and out of action. The game seems to go so fast but if you think back, you can visualise the whole storyline and you realise how much story there is that you played.And don't get me started on the music; every time I hear 'first light' and 'Strickland's march' it just gets to me how well they put the music in and made the game so unique.Every time I think about Crysis I just think to myself: 'Screw next-gen games, ♥♥♥♥ it's ahead of it's time'10/10

r 17, 2014
												As a newer PC gamer that never had the chance to play Crysis when it was released, I find the game to hold up better than all of the other Crysis games.The game feels like a PC game and not some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ port. The game treats itself seriously and allows you to tackle challenges in anyway you wantPros-Nanosuit changes on command to Stealth mode, Strength mode, Speed mode, and Defense Mode-Guns feel realistic powerful-Enemy AI is smart and will respond to your actions intelligently, which requires great awareness to overcome-Huge World-Graphics definetely hold up to this day, even for a game made almost a decade ago-Modability allows for even greater longevity-You feel like you are in control of every situation and are not limited to some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t mechanic-You can hold MULTIPLE WEAPONS. Not just limited to TWO. A pistol, 2 primaries, and explosives.Cons--Game story feels kind of similar to the original Halo's story-(this may be a individual issue) but I have issues running this game in 64 bit, with a gtx 980 and an amd fx8350. Doesn't make sense.-Can be confusing at timesOverall this game is great, and a must own for any PC gamer.

												After 7 years the game still looks just as amazing as it did when I played it the first time. Even today it's a delight to look upon, but!! That's by far not the only quality of this great introductory title to a superb franchise. Not at all. Crysis is rich with atmosphere and freedom of movement, offering a modest range of possibilities to deal with various scenarios. What I personally LOVE about this game is its pacing. You start off doing some minor guerilla oriented missions pretty much, but soon enough you become engulfed in a rather epic conflict to top it off by completely turning the world upside down somewhere in the middle... Honestly, if you've never played this game, you owe it to yourself to fix it now :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
11, 2014
												Crysis is something else: stunning graphics, an underused setting, an epic story, and an enjoyable multiplayer game to boot. People playing this will likely recall FarCry, with good reason. Crysis is the evolution of that title, using a new engine, but keeping the general feel of a 'hell in paradise'. It all begins with what looks to be like a simple rescue mission. You and your group, equipped with the latest in nano-augmented suit technology, parachute into North-Korean-occupied territory to find an archaeologist. It should be a simple rescue mission, but something is definitely wrong, and as you continue through the island you've been dropped into, you'll find that there are more players in this game than you think. The action in the single-player experience is as intensive as you want to make it. Your nano-suit grants you a variety of abilities, each of which augment what you can do and, depending on your use, how you play. You can increase your strength, adding damage to your attacks and allowing you to jump a dozen feet in the air; you can increase your speed, allowing you to run blindingly around your opponents; you can increase your armor, allowing your suit energy to take damage until it runs out and you start to bleed; or you can enter cloak mode, arguably one of the most useful suit abilities, which makes you invisible for a short time, allowing you to sneak around your opponents and confront them on your own terms.Running into the fray, guns blazing, is always an option but a difficult one. It doesn't take a lot to bring you down, and when you have at least half a dozen enemies gunning for you, things can get real deadly real quick. Hiding in the underbrush allows you to stay out of sight of enemies, which is crucial when lookout towers are scattered across the territory that you need to move through. The result is gameplay that tends to be tense at times, but at others sometimes just feels like the bushes are playing a game of hot-potato, and you're the potato.The game offers some magnificent environments, a notable difference from the usual faire in its genre. Maps span kilometres, which is an impressive feat that allows the game to be played differently than just running through small corridors. Though visually stellar, the problem with the environments is that many of them consist only of a valley that makes you move in a straight line to get to your target, as opposed to the wide-open nature of others. These valleys are probably more open than most FPS games, but they're a stark contrast to other sections of the game, and feel all the more constrained because of it.The presentation is pretty top-notch: great acting, great story, and a pace that keeps the action going throughout.The single player campaign may be fun, but it does end, and when it does, the multiplayer game is where you go to continue the action. Luckily, it delivers quite excellently. Crysis has definitely raised the stakes when it comes to graphics, and is probably going to be used as a technical benchmark for many years to come. Its stunning environments and interesting gameplay that changes with the suit's powers create a very enjoyable experience.

content:
ry 19, 2011
												Crysis is notorious for having both the highest of high end graphics and for dishing out the most punishment to your computer hardware.  But in the two+ years since release it's become a lot easier to get the hardware necessary to play, and if you've got it you owe yourself the chance to see the visual glory Crysis offers.Crysis is more than a pretty picture though; the game offers some deft gun combat that's mixed in with many opportunities to be sneaky thanks to your special powers. The vehicles however are unsatisfying to drive and the energy meter for your powers feels anemic. Fortunately the weapons you have at your disposal offer a pleasing punch allowing you to make good progress in the single player without feeling much frustration.  Storywise the game strives for believability, but it's all balderdash play acting that undermines the serious aura.  Thankfully the free-flow pacing of the game gives you ample time to breath, explore, and appreciate the visuals.

												One of the biggest reason to be a PC gamer back in 2007. With it's revolutionary graphics, and a great singleplayer, Crysis is as good as it got when it came to sandbox shooters. The Nanosuit really gives the game a different take on shooters than all the other ones out there, in a really good way. As much greatness the Crysis series has brought with it though, it brought along plenty of disappointment as well with the series getting completely butchered with Crysis 2 and Crysis 3. When it comes to Crysis, Crysis 1 and Crysis Warhead are amazing games and some of the best shooters I've played and still worth playing if you missed out on it back in the day.

content:
, 2014
												Don't expect a plot beyond your generic Sci-fi stuff. The gameplay, however, is still incredibly fun, and offers so many options that every encounter can be different. Your Nanosuit has four abilities, and the use of each one drains your suit's Energy bar. Fortunately it, as well as your health, regenerate in a decent pace to allow quick, exciting and varied combat sessions. Combined with cars and boats, as well as fairly open level designs, each fight in Crysis can be a fresh experience unlike many other shooters.Your armor has "Speed" to dart around the battlefield and rush up to enemies to knock them down. "Strength" for stronger melee, as well as high jumps (one of the favorite fights in my playthrough was using this to jump over a fence into an enemy base, and then run around their rooftops, hopping from one to the other and gunning them down as I go). "Armor" to absorb damage and hasten the recovery of Energy and Health. And lastly, "Invisibility". The stealth aspect of the game isn't as refined as it could be - silent takedowns aren't too silent and you can't hide bodies - but still enjoyable.Weapons are also modifiable to a small degree with different attachments, adding yet another layer of tactics and allowing different approaches.  Sadly, even on the toughest difficulty (which isn't as maddeningly frustrating as Modern Warfare was for me), I didn't feel a need to switch weapons out of necessity. Just for variation's sake. You can safely beat the game just with the standard rifle you'll find. But, again, experimenting is fun here.It took me 12 hours to complete, but I expect to have another playthrough eventually. Both because it's honestly a very fun shooter, and because by the end of the game you really get the hang of using your suit, vehicles and weapons, that you'll feel like revisiting those early levels where you were still fumbling around. Seeing as this isn't a linear game, those early levels /are/ worth revisiting, because the experience will thankfully be different.P.S.It's still a very pretty game, too!

content:
1, 2014
												Definitely the best sci-fi -military sandbox FPS. Crysis puts you in big, wide, dynamic levels and gives you objectives. How to do them is up to you. It's a big playground. Game doesn't give orders to you every second, make you follow a high rank-cool guy like Call of Duty games and their clones. You are the cool guy, you are the hero. It's a big fun and pleasure to play this game.It's Crysis, so we have to mention about graphics, right? :) When Crysis released in 2007, Crytek said the highest settings are for next 4-5 years' PC's. After 7 years, I can see that. I finished it again and it still has great graphics, even better graphics than many recently released games. Also it's a great pleasure to play it at highest settings at high fps (my GPU is GTX 460).But it's a shame that this awesome game continue with not that much awesome games. Crysis 2 and 3 are good games, they were fun to play but not a Crysis. They redesign the gameplay, graphics and story for consoles.It's still the best Crytek game. I hope with the new Homefront we will see Crytek making awesome games again as they used to.It's a must have if you like action games. Also it's a PC exclusive title, enjoy :) (Yes, it's released for X360 and PS3 after Crysis 2 but not like this quality graphics, and it's originally design for PC, so again, enjoy :) )Update: This game is timeless, both technically and gameplay perspective. Definitely deserves Steam's The “Test of Time” Award.

content:
y 1
												This game gives you a supersuit (called the nanosuit) that allows you four really fun abilities: cloak, maximum armour, maximum speed, and maximum strength. Cloak allows you to become almost entirely invisible and makes you feel like the Predator from the movies. Stealth is an option and a great tool for escaping situations or confusing enemies during gun battles.Maximum armour allows you to absorb more damage before your health starts getting affected. It is guaranteed to save your life in this game.Maximum speed increases your movement speed and you move so fast in sprint mode that there's a delayed reaction from enemies. I think reload speeds are slightly faster too. In fact you can sprint so fast that you'll hurt yourself if you bump into objects. Quite a nice touch.Maximum strength makes you super strong. It allows you to throw objects farther, jump much higher, inflict more damage with melee attacks (one punch kill on humans and you can punch down flimsy structures), and significantly reduce weapon recoil.All of these abilities are balanced out by your suit's energy source that gets drained and needs to be recharged frequently. In this game, you need skill in order to pull off amazing stunts while keeping an eye on your energy usage. The powersuit alone makes this game worth it in my opinion. It also helps that this game is non-linear. It is up to YOU to decide how to approach every situation (until the last third of the game). Or you can say screw the situation and go off to explore and admire the pretty environments. This game is cheap too at the moment so why not? Just make sure your computer can handle it ;)DISCLAIMER: I bought this during the winter sale when it was a steal. My opinion still stands even at $20.

content:
22, 2016
												I have to go out on a limb here and say that this is actually one of the best FPS games I ever played, period.Others may point out the deficiencies, but through the curious way I experienced this game it has ultimately assumed the status of an absolute classic in my eyes.That experience I mention is this: On my first ever playthrough, my rig was such that the game crashed as soon as I entered the final act - all that water and all those explosions, you dig? - and so I never actually knew that it was the final act. In my mind the game stretched on into inifinity - and what an infinity it was. The game goes through three distinct phases, each more jaw-droppingly perfect than the last. At first, one is navigating a jungly-coated tropical island world, evading - or annihilating, though this was never as fun for me - conventional, dastardly Korean forces in a manner strongly remeniscent of the original Far Cry (for me at least, Far Cry didn't really have any stealth component, though i did everything i could to force it to play like a stealth shooter nonetheless) In the second phase, all-out conflict has broken out and, while you can continue to play as a phantom if you wish, the stakes and scale soar upwards into 'epic' territory. In the third phase, you discover a vast and fantastic secret lurking within the island, exploring this secret in a state of permawonder, before re-emerging into a drastically altered form of the second phase, to see out the game.My initial experience was cut short most of the way through the third phase, so in my mind it was, as I've said, neverending, and by jebus that neverending game was FPS fantasy made reality. It really is just an awesome game.Quite apart form the graphics, which are to this day superior to almost any other offering of comprable setting (visually if not technolgically, though the tech is still close), the gameplay is tight and perfectly polished. This is the kind of game that, while vaguely linear, allows a player to turn 100m of linear progression into around 1km of side-track meandering and sneaking more or less throughout the entire experience. One can craft one's own adventure here, as surely as any of those gimmicky kids books from the '90s, and just as everyone had envisioned in their wildest dreams back then this adventure is lush, endless and full of wonders more wonderous than the last.The gameplay is consistent and with the possible exception of the final moments of the second phase, in which combat is more or less forced on you and the game literally ejects any background action in an effort - only marginally succesful - to turn your final stage into some kind of arena, it is consistently entertaining.Why should you buy this game? Because your computer may very well finally be able to run it in something approaching max settings, because it is one of the best FPS experiences you will ever play, and because it is streets, miles ahead of any other similar game released in the years before or the years after.

												I felt compelled to write this. I've been playing video games ever since the Nintendo entertainment system was released in 85. I'm in my 30s now and I did not have a PC that could run this game when it was released. I've played all the big AAA's on PC old and new but always overlook this one. I purchased Crisis 2 and Crisis 3 again overlooking this one it's too old I keep telling myself. Purchased it on this recent sale. Researched some mods Texter foliage lighting etc. Installed them hopped on and OMG what a game. Not only is it beautiful and I mean beautiful. It has amazing AI an awesome story. The immersion is through the roof. If you immerse yourself in the game enough with a headset on you almost think you're in a Rambo movie. It has the old school difficulty of days gone by. The amazing destruction beautiful visuals (with mods) that today's games cannot capture. Battlefield 4 Call of Duty Ghost Assassins creed black flag don't come close visually or technically. What an amazing game I have been missing out all of these years. Of course it's taken 30+ years to be able to afford a rig that can run this and all of its glory. This game truly is a masterpiece.

content:
y 17, 2015
												Crysis is still a game hog on today's machines.  However, it's a must play for anyone that wants to feel like they have full control on how the game is played.  Do you want to go guns blazing?  Do you want to use stealth?  You get to choose how you can take on each mission.  However, the world is not as open as Far Cry was, it is much more linear.  The graphics are some of the best graphics still even by today's standard and the action is non-stop.  The story, however, isn't that great.  Luckily the visual/audio of this game make up for any loss.  The ability to configure your gun and the added skills that are part of the nano-suit add some RPG elements to a wonderful FPS experience.  Definitely a classic to be played by all fans of the genre.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												This game kinda sucks. I know its old, and for its time the graphics were amazing, but I just cant get over some pifalls of the gameplay. I know reviewing a game past its prime, you have to take things in consideration, but somethings I cant get over.First thing you want to do is bind the suit powers to a certain key. You cant do this. Why?  Honestly, thats why this game gets a bad review. Im sure there might be a mod that I could download but im not wasting my time. Using the toggle suit powers doesnt work, and having to use the wheel toggle to flip back and forth is slow, I feel defeats the purpose of the suit. You cant melee guys that dont see you for an instant kill.  Some cue appears to grab enemy but I could never get it to work properly. I have this badass suit but no knife? Really? The AI is horrible. I play games on hard and ultra hard, and I hate games where you are forced to use glitches to kill guys on ultra hard. Half the time they dont see you when they clearly should, and other times they see you immediately when they shouldnt.  And that sucks because the game relys heavily on stealth.  I dont quite see the purpose of the silencer.  If you kill a guy with a silencer everyone hears it. Using the Speed Power boost doesnt frighten or stagger the enemies at all, which I find really dumb. If I zip past 2 guys you would think their would be some delay before they would just turn around and kill me. Nope. Pick up another pistol, and youll duel weild automatically and lose the iron sights on the pistol.  I never figured out how to single wield, and you cant aim with pistol anymore.  Dont pick up another pistol, and youll have no pistol ammo.Whats the biggest dissappointment is that you would think with the suit powers there would be some sort of combos or different play styles. There isnt. Strength is for jumping and breaking walls, speed is for getting around the map, armor is used for combat, stealth is what your forced to be in most of the time.I just found it kind of lame because of these problems.  The story seems really good though.

ry 22, 2015
												Crysis is a Sci-Fi First Person Shooter.About the Game:You are an army man on a mission from a special task force with a suit, mabye this doesn't sound original but the gameplay is super.What makes this game good if you look to the other FPS games ???The suit... gives you power to ... run fast... jump high or be invisible.You fight your way on a island and play how you want to play.Be like Rambo or sneak like Sold Snake (Metal Gear Solid)The games has a amazing story mode and makes the game worth buying and playing.Game looks amazing and this was the first game in my life where I purchased a 300 euro video card just to play it.I think a lot of people did the same or know what I'm talking about.For me it was a new reason to spend a ♥♥♥♥ load of money on a core 2 duo or quad core pc.Only now you can play the game with a basic GTX650 Ti or higher card,Single Player:Some parts of the game gives you the freedom to go everywhere you like to go.The maps are gigantic and a lot of stiff to explore.Some parts are pure rail shooters... you walk the way and try to defeat your enemies.I think this game has not special story line only it's really great to play and experiance.Not graphic part wil not be a problem for many VGA cards. Yes most games will look better now on the day I made this review.Still Crysis looks amazing and will give you a very good experience.And will let you give a look in the story mode / world of Crysis.MultiPlayer Option:Crysis whas made as a single player demo and the multiplayer has not been updated after the Wars addon.The Basic crysis had only deathmatch and power struggle.Deathmatch is free for all and power strungle is more like a capture the points and earn money to buy new weapons.So this multiplayer is extreme basic as it can be only funny thing is.This whas one of the best multiplayer games i've been played after all these years.Yes it is basic... but freaking good !!Just basic FPS multiplayer fun for LAN or to play with friends online.Everybody has the same suits... no upgrades.. and there are weapons to find and pick up.I had so much fun with this game in LAN partiesPlayed it for more than 500 hours and enjoyed every hour.When I noticed that the game was on sale on Steam for a few euros I bought it right away.Overall:I think this is a must have game for every FPS fan.Epic Game, Good Story, Basic Multiplayer and has a small history if you ask me.That's why I give it a 9/10 score.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
17, 2014
												Let me start by saying Crysis is a very different game to what I expected.  Boy was I wrong and I am GLAD for it. I was expecting to step into the shoes of a Master Chief style tank/super soldier that could Clint Eastwood his way through the fight. Crysis instead puts you into the shoes of an American Special Forces soldier and asks you to think like one. It was VERY refreshing and VERY welcome. The Nano Suit (think super soldier suit) which you wear doesn't make you an invincible force of nature but instead makes you feel like you are wearing a USEFUL military designed peice of hardware. It expands the natural abilities that a special forces soldier would need and use, not grant him super powers. The suit merely gives you options to tackle any situation how you see fit and THAT is what makes this game clever. I also want to put on record that I know and understand that the Crysis series is designed to break computers. I played this game on Maximum settings as intended and it is FREAKING GORGEOUS. A game that came out in 2007 still beats out most modern day titles that I have seen in 2014. It is wonderful to be awed by the graphics of a game to this extent and I am blessed to own a computer that could handle it easily (although I do feel that this would be a sticking point for many players with underpowered hardware). Just because my experience was great, doesn't mean your experience will be. Please understand that your milage could vary from my review!So I finished the game in 12 hours (which is leaning on the shorter side)  but the story and the pacing complimented this length nicely so it is hard to chalk this as adrawback. I also played with a gamepad (Xbox 360) but it is easy to tell that Crysis is designed with the Keyboard and Mouse in mind. It works don't get me wrong! But it isn't always natural.So in conclusion I HIGHLY recommend Crysis. It is smarter than it appears.

content:
ry 23, 2014
												This is still one of the best looking games available. I'm not someone to buy a game just because the graphics look nice but this is a must own for anyone that can appreciate detail and great level design. The giant island sandbox, mixed with highly destructible environments makes this game shine. There's nothing like getting on a heavy machine gun turrent, mowing down everyone in front of you while trees are being cut down, dirt chunks are flying into the air and small shacks are getting destroyed crumbling into pieces. Or throwing a grenade into a small village full of enemies and watching sheet metal fly, walls being blown apart while enemies fly into them.The games only downfall is it starts out very slow, but just stick with it, the more you progress the more the game throws at you and you'll be in some great fire fights.If you have this game (and played it very little) or want to buy it do yourself a favor and download Tactical Expansion Mod V1.1. This mod is a must while playing this game. Adds better blood effects, ramps up the AI, and adds a ton of new weapons and attachments.

content:
er 30, 2016
												Quite simply the greatest game of all time. If you choose to buy it, I thoroughly suggest the Tactical Expansion Mod you can get online for free. Adds a TON of weapons and rebalances the game somewhat. My first playthrough, I played it like a shooter with cloak. Stealth killed a bunch of dudes with silenced weapons, occassionally went rambo. But soon I realized that while that is really fun its still not the most fun way to play this game. What I started doing was turning my nanosuit to speed mode, running into enemy encampments, switching to strength mode after I've built up momentum and doing a superjump, preferably over a fence or up a balcony to deliver an absolute wrath of god punch that obliterates some poor korean. Or leaving one guy alive as you superjump from building to building and laugh as he tries to hit you. If you run at enemies at superspeed, you knock them down without dealing damage. If you jump on top of a guy trying to get up you knock him down again. If you jump on top of a guy he won't detect it. I've spent hours just trolling the NPCs, whether it be by doing that or picking up bulletproof objects and slowly walking at them while shouting "I AM BULLETPROOF" before throwing it at them in strength mode. Strapping C4 to barrels and vehicles and driving or throwing them into groups of enemies. Tactical expansion adds among a lot of other things a lot more explosives, such as like 4 or 5 nuclear grenades and explosive ammunition hidden through the levels that are incredibly op and entertaining to use. I'd buy this game for $100 and if it had 1990s graphics. The far cry series, dishonored, metro, half life, bioshock, deus ex, I've played through a lot of them, but they all pale in comparison to the brilliance and unending fun that is this game. If at any point you feel yourself getting slightly bored, try imposing a restriction on yourself. For instance, I've gotten to the aliens part using only my fists, c4 and landmines, and without using cloak.

												If this game (and franchise) isn´t a CLASSIC, It will be in a few years.I recently received and finished "Crysys 3" on PS3 and it´s now one of my favorites games of all time. It got me genuinely interested to know how did it all started for this franchise, so in this last Steam Sale I got to buy the "Crysis Package" (10$) which came with the 1st 2 games and the (prequel/standalone?) "Crysys Warhead".I just finished the 1st game and (for the time it was released) the graphics and gameplay are superb. It´s as addictive to play as the 3rd entry (even though it´s way better) and the story is very interesting. I loved the fact that this game has a satisfying BEGGINING, MIDDLE and END.My final verdict for this game would´ve been an 8/10.It provides a very solid experience but I actually found a few bugs (regarding the enemies) in 2 of it´s levels that made me restart the missions where I was in. It provides a bit of variety in it´s level designs more at the end but it might become a bit boring for some people in the first few levels. The "Nanosuit" is an awesome idea but it´s not as strong as it could´ve been, since the "jumping higher" mechanic is barely used and the "stealth" mechanic never worked (for me at least) even on easy difficulty. The only mechanic I found most usefull was the "fast running" in order to get to the missions faster. Even though I replayed the last checkpoint of the final mission twice, I never got to see the ending cutscene because of a bug I guess.These are the reasons why my final verdict for this game is a 7.5/10.This IS (or will become) a great CLASSIC.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 10, 2012
												Just to get it out of the way: yes, this game is gorgeous, one of the best looking of all time and it still is today. However, I've never been particularly a good graphics kind of gamer, I'm more about the gameplay in games. Luckily, the gameplay in Crysis is a lot of fun. The thing that really makes it is the nanosuit, giving you four different abilities to use: speed, strength, armour, and invisibility. Mixing and matching these four modes is a lot of fun, and allows for a lot of experimentation during combat. Stealth is also a crucial strategy, especially when there are dozens of enemies you have to eliminate. The enemy AI is very good as well, it works very well with stealth and during combat they will try to flank you. Add in the different weapon customizations, there are a lot of combinations to use in enemy encounters that it will keep you entertained for the duration of the campaign. The level design is also nice and open, giving you even more options like sniping and using vehicles.The story in the game isn't particularly good, but this isn't the kind of game you play for the story, you should play it for the gameplay and graphics. However, where the game really faulters, is in the last two or two-and-a-half hours of the campaign when you start battling the aliens. The aliens just aren't as fun to fight as the Koreans and don't allow for much variation in the ways you want to fight them.Crysis is a great game, particularly is you like experimentation in the ways you want to handle the enemy encounters.  Half the fun is just seeing what kind of stuff you can get away with, and I love that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												In 2007 Turkish-German game developer Crytek released ‘Crysis’, a cryengine-built first person shooter which exceeded the graphical norm at the time more than any other game ever did or would later do. Almost no computer could run it at the time and for many years it would be the ideal game to test new gaming PC’s with, but even disregarding this main strength of the game Crysis is a very decent FPS. In Crysis you take the role of an American soldier named ‘Nomad’ who is part of an elite squadron of nanosuit-equipped soldiers . You are sent to the Lingshan islands in the pacific to rescue a team of archeologists from North-Korean soldiers who took the place over. Story is not quite the part of the game that deserves closest examination because of that it is quite generic. After all, even back in 2007 there were already quite a few games that had the player kill soldiers while playing as an American soldier himself, but luckily the story takes a bit of a back seat here. It would not be until Crysis 2 that other things than combat would be given some attention. In terms of story delivery there is also nothing new here.What you would want to play Crysis for, if not the superb graphics, would be its gameplay and it does this quite well. Although it uses pretty standard FPS mechanisms the nanosuit makes for a welcome addition. Basically the suit gives you a choice of four superpowers, which consume from one general energy bar. There is a speed mode, pretty self-explanatory, a cloak mode that makes you largely invisible, a power mode that lets you jump higher and fling heavy objects and an armour mode. Using whatever improvements your power gives you costs energy and generally this system holds up pretty well. It is nice that you are given the choice between stealthing a section with the cloak or fighting through it normally, and if you choose the latter you can also pick different tactics with either the speed or the armour mode.  A nice small addition on the side is that you are at any time able to modify your weapon, which means you can pick your sight, add a suppressor or make other small modifications. The game also excels in giving the player freedom. Before Crytek set about on making Crysis they made the original Far Cry. Why these developers are so attached to the word ‘cry’ remains a mystery. But anyway, Far Cry was an open world game which was, like Crysis, set on a tropical island and sometimes it seems as if the developers carved a big and wide linear path out of Far Cry’s sandbox to make Crysis because Crysis feels about as unlinear as a linear game can be. The entire game has a structure similar to Half Life 2, in that you are never teleported to a different location but always go there yourself. There are almost no missions that all of a sudden take place somewhere else unless the last mission had you go there by yourself. Some objectives give you entire towns to play around in, a lot of the houses can be smashed up and most objects can be grabbed and thrown as weapons. What also makes this game feel like some fenced-off sandbox is the completely free use of vechiles. When you need to go to the next firefight you can walk there if you want, or you can get in a car which the game just puts outside most villages. Driving mechanics are not very good though, so if you are being shot at you are in more danger in a car than on foot.Although Crysis is indeed a very good FPS it does have a few minor issues I want to mention. Firstly that would be the story. I understand that a game like this leaves little room for something outrageously good, but they could perhaps have done a little less effort to make the North-Koreans look like jerks because in a game based around so much military excessive force, as showcased in a level where you take part in a big tank offensive, making the enemy seem evil just puts the entire game in a big cliché. Of course in a game with such a simple story you want to have your side as the goodies and the other side to be the baddies, but emphasizing that so much makes it all feel a bit fake. Some enemies come across as silly cartoon villains. My other nibbles mostly restrict to specific sections and mentioning them spoils parts of the game for you, so be warned about the following part. What peeved me a bit about one level that takes place in an alien space ship was that the entire place is extremely disorienting. Although that bit still looks extremely gorgeous graphics-wise, I found myself moving through the same looped corridor about five times before I found the right way by accident and the beauty loses something if it is forced upon you for so long. Another annoying part was one section where your squadmate, ‘Prophet’, has a damaged nanosuit which means you have to escort him and bring him to some kind of heat source every few seconds to prevent him from dying. It is not even hard at all and the combat is not harder with him around, so the entire thing just feels like a silly delay.  On the side, I found the game’s soundtrack to be very unimaginative. It does nothing to increase the atmosphere.So, in conclusion I would certainly recommend Crysis, even today. Although the graphics don’t excel anymore and the story is pretty rubbish, the gameplay is still very nice and you have plenty of liberty to explore the nanosuits potential, and that certainly outweighs the game’s few issues.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
17, 2014
												Let me start by saying Crysis is a very different game to what I expected.  Boy was I wrong and I am GLAD for it. I was expecting to step into the shoes of a Master Chief style tank/super soldier that could Clint Eastwood his way through the fight. Crysis instead puts you into the shoes of an American Special Forces soldier and asks you to think like one. It was VERY refreshing and VERY welcome. The Nano Suit (think super soldier suit) which you wear doesn't make you an invincible force of nature but instead makes you feel like you are wearing a USEFUL military designed peice of hardware. It expands the natural abilities that a special forces soldier would need and use, not grant him super powers. The suit merely gives you options to tackle any situation how you see fit and THAT is what makes this game clever. I also want to put on record that I know and understand that the Crysis series is designed to break computers. I played this game on Maximum settings as intended and it is FREAKING GORGEOUS. A game that came out in 2007 still beats out most modern day titles that I have seen in 2014. It is wonderful to be awed by the graphics of a game to this extent and I am blessed to own a computer that could handle it easily (although I do feel that this would be a sticking point for many players with underpowered hardware). Just because my experience was great, doesn't mean your experience will be. Please understand that your milage could vary from my review!So I finished the game in 12 hours (which is leaning on the shorter side)  but the story and the pacing complimented this length nicely so it is hard to chalk this as adrawback. I also played with a gamepad (Xbox 360) but it is easy to tell that Crysis is designed with the Keyboard and Mouse in mind. It works don't get me wrong! But it isn't always natural.So in conclusion I HIGHLY recommend Crysis. It is smarter than it appears.

												This is just an awesome game, which came out in 2007 and remained the benchmark for hardware for many years preceeding it's release. "But can it run Crysis?"Forget multiplayer, as Gamespy is no longer around, but for single player, it is up there with the best. A modern quad core processor with even a Radeon 6670 will play this game at 1080p with everything maxed out and it still looks great.For those of you running Windows 7 64bit, you may encounter a blank screen when trying to execute the game, this was resolved for me by the following method:-Search for and download Bin64.zip, and extract itGo to:  Steam\steamapps\common\Crysis (or wherver you have it installed)Cut out your Bin32 file and stick it somewhere safeCopy in your downloaded Bin64 file and rename it to Bin32Re-execute the game and now you should be able to play normally

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 23, 2014
												This is still one of the best looking games available. I'm not someone to buy a game just because the graphics look nice but this is a must own for anyone that can appreciate detail and great level design. The giant island sandbox, mixed with highly destructible environments makes this game shine. There's nothing like getting on a heavy machine gun turrent, mowing down everyone in front of you while trees are being cut down, dirt chunks are flying into the air and small shacks are getting destroyed crumbling into pieces. Or throwing a grenade into a small village full of enemies and watching sheet metal fly, walls being blown apart while enemies fly into them.The games only downfall is it starts out very slow, but just stick with it, the more you progress the more the game throws at you and you'll be in some great fire fights.If you have this game (and played it very little) or want to buy it do yourself a favor and download Tactical Expansion Mod V1.1. This mod is a must while playing this game. Adds better blood effects, ramps up the AI, and adds a ton of new weapons and attachments.

												As I played this game from 2007 in 2014, all graphics settings could be maxed out. I was amazed that a 7 year old game, could deliver such an enjoyable experience! Especially as FPS tend to depend alot on their graphics performance. Crysis provided a good mix of stealth, full-on action, vehicular combat and differing environments. The nanosuit deserves a special mention as it adds gameplay due to the capabilities of the suit. Overall, a highly recommended golden classic!Score: 8.5/10Pro: + very nice graphics (even if the game is almost 7 years old!)+ nanosuit capabilities+ excellent gameplay+ semi-open world+ decent amount of mods available on the internet (didn't try any)Contra:- too short; 10 to 15 hours to complete- some enemy A.I. & graphics glitches

content:
28, 2013
												I remember when this was considered a trial by fire for anyone's computer, even today some low end rigs struggle to run it.It's a nice game, perhaps set back by it's stiffy for post-processing, but there's a functional experience here at least, it annoyed me that the multiplayer didn't have vehicles, that was introduced in Crysis Warhead.Aaaaanyway, Crysis begins when your squad is sent to the Lingshan islands to rescue a research team who have uncovered something big, and dangerous. Ancient technology of an alien civilization buried in the earth.And now I'm sitting in the same pose as that History Channel bloke, ALIENS.Outside of combatting an awakening alien scourge, you fight against a division of the Korean Military who have occupied the island due to the discovery, using stealth, wits, various vehicles, and your Nanosuit to overcome the challenges facing you.The game also features a realtime weapon modification mechanic, allowing you to swap out attachments and ammo types on the fly, you unlock these attachments as you find them ingame, my personal recommendation is to use an assault scope and a silencer on your FY-71, and then keep a Precision Rifle with a Sniper scope handy for those crucial shots.I will not spoil any of the game's major plot points, play it for yourself if you are interested.

												A schizophrenic gameplay experience that can't decide what it wants to be, punishing the player for taking one role for more than 10 seconds at a time, even a well designed engine with such potential for tweaking and customisation can't save this game and it's trite, overdone, and lackluster story. While you can easily see where the influence of this game came from, I am going to complete this review without any reference to Halo. The most notable detail, one that you'll see as soon as you begin playing, is the scenery. The aesthetically pleasing environment of this FPS puts all others to shame. However, while the levels seem quite open and non-linear at a glance, they feel limited. The numbers in this game need a serious overhaul and a definite position on whether or not it's a stealth game, a cover-based shooter, or a terminator versus the horde game.

content:
, 2014
												Ah the infamous Crysis. A game that required such high graphical settings to run it perfectly when it was released, there actually wasn't a computer available that could run it at those settings. Nowaways, it's not such a chore but the game still has heavy requirements. But it shows as this is a graphically beautiful game. But since gameplay comes before graphics, how does it play? Very well in fact. It is a first person shooter, which I usually avoid unless the game has an extra quality to make it stand out. Crysis places you, for most of the game, in indivudual mission areas which are huge. It's not quite an open world experience but it comes close, as you need to navigate to your objective and complete it, all the while dodging or kill hostiles. The other thing that sets the game apart is the Nanosuit; in this game it features four modes, which are strength, armor, speed, and stealth. Strength gives you a super jump and steady aim, armor reduces damage, speed makes you run faster, and stealth allows you cloak and ambush enemies or avoid them altogther. Of course the trick is that you can't have them all active at one time and you have a limited energy reserve which needs to recharge once empty. Trying to balance these out is half of the fun as you need to strategize and think on the fly if things go wrong.Crysis also features a good selection of weaponry, with explosives ranging from a missile launcher to claymore mines, along with single or dual wield pistols, and several different automatic and semi-automatic rifles. On these you can equip iron, or reflex sights, silencers, scopes, whatever you want (depending on the weapon). Some even offer non-lethal ammo or incendiary ammo. A couple of spots in the game get a little claustrophobic and hard to navigate, and the story isn't the game's strong point (secret U.S. rescue mission near Korea goes wrong, and aliens appear out of nowhere requiring fighting against both the aliens and Korean troops) but it's worth a pickup. Of note is the fact that online multiplayer for this game is being shut down in Summer of 2014 so when purchasing, keep in mind you'll have only the single player campaign.The game is highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2014
												Regardless of the date of production of this title, it gets a solid 10/10 for being polished.  That said, it was ahead of its time, and I beleive has had an impact on the industry and customer satisfaction even across genres due to the hardware driven nature of this title. Even if you do not delve into the hardware and system tweaking discussions that can be evoked by even mentioning the name Crysis at all, you are left with a great game conceptually and artistically.  The story-telling and voice/character acting are very seamless, and all the entire architecture of the game design is cohesive.  I was pleasently surprised to see the game evolve from remote island views to frozen SCI-FI worlds that are revealed in a manner that is very enthralling.  The plot and enemy design are the best things about this game to me, and they are why I think it is hard to put this game down even years after its debut (although the graphics are what made me interested in the game to begin with).    Unfortunately, it has taken all those years since its release for me to fully appreciate and realize this, as I could not get to the interesting parts without system lags interfering with the enjoyable quality of the game.  I found the game hard to enjoy at 15FPS, and I think anyone who has played this game on maximum settings without frame drops would not trade the experience. When Crysis came out, you would be lucky to get 30FPS on maxed out settings on a medium-high end PC.  This probably is no longer the case and you can enjoy what was at the time about the closest thing to being in control of an interactive movie on your system. This game continues to push hardware limits, and today is probably much more accessible to the average gamer than it was when it was first released and barely playable without spending a mere fortune.  The graphics are just as stunning as the physics, and the CRY-engine is polished but can be laggy at times compared to more light-weight games (depending on your system specifications).  The most optimized platforms at max settings continue to respect real-world dynamics and rigid body interactions/physics in a more satisfying manner than most competitive games/engines do with respect to fluid/solid body motions and raycasting/tracing in my opinion. I did find the environments and modeling of terrain to be more photorealistic in Crysis 1 as compared to its sequel; however, my system still has trouble handling the DX-11 patches for Crysis-2 on max settings on HD6990 Radeon and IntelX990.  This game is fun just because it is hard to talk about it without discussing the hardware and graphics, but I do think the animation style, branding and abundance of environmental details are what carried this game into public visibility and have secured it a place in videogame history.  At the end of the day, it is a beautiful game with extreme longevity with regards to its visual presentation.

content:
er 23, 2016
												This is a game that had so awesome graphics when it came out that even now it stands the test of time. I remember back when I played it for the first time when I reached the Korean camp I was looking at slideshow rather than playing a game. Every time I did an upgrade on my PC I revisited Crysis to check how the visuals of the game.But important: the game is not only about the graphics. It is an open, strategic fps game that can be played multiple time each time focusing on a different style: from tank, to hitman to stealth.Pros:+ Awesome graphics especially, a visual revolution when it came out+ nice setting, open world, multiple possibilities to achieve goals+ large variety of vehicles to drive+ at instances it really feels that you participate in a greater war+ nice soundtrack and effects+ excellent physics+ some scripted moments that are awesome, especially with boss battles+ variety of enemies+ atmosphere close to the "Predator" movieCons:- ok, the initial wow factor especially of the visuals after so many years is not there, but still it looks beautiful- the second part of the game is perhaps a bit too linear compared to the first one- when it came out it required a monster PC to play at maximum- some vehicle combats are perhaps too generic compared to the fps part.All-in-all an awesome fps that excels in visuals but the gameplay part is also very nicely done.MASTERPIECE.As a note, in my opinion both sequels did not manage to capture the awesomeness of the first Crysis.  The second one, even if equally impressive in visuals, was too console-oriented, Halo-wannabe.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 15, 2016
												I've been itching to be the badass in the suit for some time, and as our protagonist is an uber-macho ultra-masculine Iron Man, it can be quite entertaining to tromp around in his NanoBoots. However I was disappointed by some of the glaring technical issues which have been left unattended by CryTek since its arrival on Steam.You wear the NanoSuit in the first iteration of the photorealistic experience, becoming the ultimate soldier. Prepare to Maximum your way through enemy forces, alien strongholds and countless gorgeously rendered trees and foliage.Crysis was for nearly a decade the gold standard for performance: "Sure the server's fast, but will it run Crysis?" Modern systems can still be tasked by the demanding CryEngine in its earliest release. Unfortunately it has not aged well, and graphical flaws can break the visual flow, such as spawning objects incorrectly and even breaking mission targets.Electronic Arts and Crytek issued their final patches in 2007, and it has not received any attention since, which casts a shadow on its asking price. Do not pay full price for this game. Instead, buy it as part a bundle or in a sale. It is a satisfying experience for the hardcore, and even casual shooter.Stone dumb AI amuses more often than frustrate, and once you learn their recognition patterns, you're nearly untouchable. All that said, this is a fun futuristic if somewhat thoughtfless romp.

content:
15, 2015
												***Written in a nostalgic saturday night***I started playing it when I was 13 years old, back in March 2008, I had to buy a new graphics card for my computer, an nVidia 9600GT, to be able to run the game with almost everything at minimum. And well, that breathtaking HALO jump intro hooked me into an incredible game with features that I hadn't experienced before. My mind was completely blown with this game. I played hours and hours and I enjoyed it so much, too bad my parents wouldn't let me play as much I wanted :(**tears running down my face**I even enjoyed with the most simple things I could do in this game, like picking up a cute turtle or a chicken, and throw it hundreds of meters away. Or hiting those tropical buildings smashing them into pieces, or driving like a crazy driver, or having a swim on a paradise beach while the sun was setting and some northkoreans were yelling strange things...**maximum nostalgia**Now, time for my subjective and totally parcial review. I can only give this game a 10/10 because what it meant at that time: -no one ever had done a similar gameplay concept before-the graphics were very advanced, and even today looks really nice-The crytek engine, it was mind-blowing. At that time, who could ever think that it would possible to have so much freedom in a game? that it would be possible to pick up random animals and throw them away or even use them as weapons?-The multiplayer, it put very well all that freedom into an online gameplay with a fair amount of players and very big maps-To sum up, it became a reference in no time after release. Everyone would use it as a reference when comparing graphics , when building a new PC, when comparing gameplay features.... And the famous words "NASA computer" became one of the most used for years thanks to this game. Can the NASA computers run it today with all settings at max? :P
